Even with her admirable traits, which are countless, you can't completely love her, for she holds a deep seeded hatred for her bastard step-child, Jon Snow, who is very undeserving of this.<br /><br />Queen Cersei: A cruel villian plotting to have her son on the throne, her manipulations are intelligent and evil, far beyond anything that a common bar whore could come up with.<br /><br />Sansa Stark: A prude at first who blossoms into the image of her mother and as of book four has yet to be deflowered, thus making her not a whore.<br /><br />Ayra Stark: A tomboy who looks like her father and later joins a mysterious guild. She holds a terrible grudge against so many people, reciting all of their names to inspire her every day. B000NVIXFK|5.0|Despite what some other reviewers are saying, this may be Rush's best album in 25 years. Not only is it beautifully mastered (unlike Vapor Trails!), but the compositions are fresh and solid, the performances are intricate and impressive, the album is cohesive and tight throughout, and the whole work is brimming with nuance and an uncompromised spirit that isn't always found in their previous works. It all just feels wonderfully honest and fresh. This is a true gem, especially so late in their career!    **EDIT: 3 WEEKS LATER***  Ok, I'll admit I reviewed this album a little early, on the first day of release only after a few listens. It grabbed my attention so far past expectation that I couldn't resist. Three weeks later, however, my opinion hasn't changed, and this disc hasn't left my player.    Far removed from the ostentatious, showy presentations found in their other works, this album whirrs along gracefully from start to finish, with nearly perfect balance and posture throughout. Very little is out of place here: musicianship, solid songwriting, breathing space, elegant grace and form, nuance, superb sound, crisp production, contemporary aesthetic value - and last but not least, EMOTION. These are, quite frankly, some of the best songs they've ever written. I have never been so moved on such an innately human level by any other Rush album; they've simply never sounded so sublime. Rush really hit home with this record - a true classic in the making.

How could this happen to two perfect children?  <br /> <br />I'd heard that Piccoult tries to deal with real life issues in her novels, and she does a pretty good job in the first half of this book. How well do parents really know their kids? What goes on beneath the placid surface of upper middle class small town life? Like other reviewers, I found it hard to absolve Chris from some of the blame. In addition, the courtroom scenes come to a ludicrous conclusion--the lawyer in me rebelled at how totally impossible the end of the book would be in real life. I'd put this in the category of an airplane book at best--light,fast-paced and decently written but not to be taken seriously.

1400063515|5.0|A fine antidote to gullibility - A Must Read!<br /><br />According to critic Harold Bloom, Hamlet's predicament is not \\"that he thinks too much\\" but rather that \\"he thinks too well,\\" being ultimately \\"unable to rest in illusions of any kind.\\" The same could be said for philosopher, essayist and trader Nassim Nicholas Taleb, who finds something rotten in misguided yet supremely confident investment gurus, traders, hedge fund managers, Wall Street bankers, M.B.A.s, CEOs, Nobel-winning economists and others who claim that they can predict the future and explain the past. Like everyone else, says Taleb, these so-called \\"experts\\" fail to appreciate \\"black swans\\": highly consequential but unlikely events that render predictions and standard explanations worse than worthless.<br /><br />Talebst book starts with this: Before 1697, teachers confidently taught European schoolchildren that all swans were white. They had little reason to think otherwise, since every swan ever examined had the same snowy plumage. But then Dutch explorer Willem de Vlamingh landed in Australia. Among the many unlikely creatures down under - odd, hopping marsupials called kangaroos, furry duck-billed platypuses, teddy bear-like koalas - Vlamingh found dark feathered birds that looked remarkably like swans. Black swans? Indeed. Once observed, they were as unmistakable as they had been unimaginable, and they forced Europeans to revise forever their concept of \\"swan.\\" In time, black swans came to seem ordinary.<br /><br />This pattern is common. Just because you haven't seen a black swan, doesn't mean that there are no black swans. Unlikely events seem impossible when they lie in the unknown or in the future. But after they happen, people assimilate them into their conception of the world. The extraordinary becomes ordinary, and \\"experts\\" such as policy pundits and market prognosticators kick themselves because they didn't predict the (now seemingly obvious) occurrence of the (then) unlikely event. Think of the advent of World Wars I and II, the terrorist attacks of 9/11, the popping of the 1990s Internet stock bubble, or world-changing inventions like the internal combustion engine, the personal computer and the Internet. Cultural fads like the Harry Potter books are the same. These events and inventions came out of nowhere, yet in hindsight they seem almost inevitable. Why?<br /><br />The human mind is wonderful at simplifying the onslaught of today's \\"booming, buzzing confusion\\" of data. This makes perfect sense: After all, the brain is the product of evolution, which works with what it has, and so it has not crafted some new, ideal cognitive mechanism. The human brain is a marvel, but it is built for living in hunter-gatherer groups on the African savannah 200,000 years ago. Then, it just needed to be good enough to allow humans to survive until they reached reproductive age. Simplifications, mental schemas, heuristics, biases, self-deception - these are not \\"bugs\\" in the cognitive system, but useful features that allow the human mind to concentrate on the task at hand and not get overwhelmed by a literally infinite amount of data. But human simplifying mechanisms are not without their costs. Take stories, for example.<br /><br />Stories help people remember and make sense of the past. Think of a typical business magazine profile of a successful businessman. The story begins in the present, after he has become rich beyond his wildest dreams. The story then cuts back to his humble beginnings. He started with nothing and wanted to get rich (in terms of story structure, his \\"dramatic need\\"). He faced obstacle after obstacle (perhaps he had a rival - the \\"antagonist\\"). But he made shrewd decisions and flouted the wisdom of the Cassandras who counseled caution (\\"Idiots!\\"). As success built on success, he amassed a fortune. He retired early, married a model and now has brilliant children who play Chopin blindfolded and will all attend Ivy League colleges. His virtues will be extolled in a B-School case study. Wide-eyed M.B.A. students will sit rapt at his feet when he visits their schools on a lecture tour promoting his latest book. He is a superman, an inspiration.<br /><br />Now consider an alternative hypothesis: He got lucky. His putative \\"virtues\\" had nothing to do with his success. He is, essentially, a lottery winner. The public looks at his life and concocts a story about how brilliant he was, when, in fact, he was merely at the right place at the right time. This is the \\"ludic fallacy\\" (ludus means game in Latin): People underestimate luck in life - though they ironically overestimate it in certain games of \\"chance.\\" Even the businessman himself falls victim to flawed thinking through the self-sampling bias. He looks at himself, a sample of one, and draws a sweeping conclusion, such as, \\"If I can do it, anyone can!\\" Notice that the same reasoning would apply had he merely bought a winning lottery ticket. \\"I'm a genius for picking 3293927! Those long odds didn't mean a darn thing. I mean, after all, I won didn't I!\\"<br /><br />Not all success is luck. In some professions, skill matters (for example, if you are a dentist), but luck dominates in others. In the case of the inspiring businessman, consider his population cohort. Where are all the similarly situated people who started out like him and have the same attributes? Are they also rich? Or homeless? Usually you can't find this sort of \\"silent\\" disconfirming evidence. Artistic success provides a perfect illustration. While Balzac is famous now, perhaps countless other equally talented writers were producing comparable work at the same time. Yet their writings are lost to posterity because they did not succeed. Their \\"failure\\" hides the evidence that would undercut Balzac's \\"success\\" as a uniquely great writer. The evidence is silent, lost in the graveyard of history.<br /><br />The mind uses many more simplifying schemas that can lead to error. Once people have theories, they seek confirming evidence; this is called \\"confirmation bias.\\" They fall victim to \\"epistemic arrogance,\\" becoming overconfident about their ideas and failing to account for randomness. To make their theories work, people \\"smooth out\\" the \\"jumps\\" in a time series or historical sequence, looking for and finding patterns that are not there. Their conceptual categories will limit what they see; this is called \\"tunneling.\\" They turn to \\"experts\\" for help, but often these expert opinions are no better - and often they are worse - than the \\"insights\\" gained from flipping a coin or hiring a trained chimp to throw darts at the stock listings. Worst of all, people steadily fail to consider \\"black swans,\\" the highly consequential rare events that drive history.<br /><br />Taleb's style is personal and literary, his heterodox insights are rigorous. This combination makes for a thrilling, disturbing, contentious and unforgettable book on chance and randomness. While Taleb offers strong medicine some readers may find too bitter at times, we prescribe it to anyone who wants a powerful inoculation against gullibility. One of the best non-fiction books of this decade.e study. Wide-eyed M.B.A. students will sit rapt at his feet when he visits their schools on a lecture tour promoting his latest book. He is a superman, an inspiration.    Now consider an alternative hypothesis: He got lucky. His putative \\"virtues\\" had nothing to do with his success. He is, essentially, a lottery winner. The public looks at his life and concocts a story about how brilliant he was, when, in fact, he was merely at the right place at the right time. This is the \\"ludic fallacy\\" (ludus means game in Latin): People underestimate luck in life - though they ironically overestimate it in certain games of \\"chance.\\" Even the businessman himself falls victim to flawed thinking through the self-sampling bias. He looks at himself, a sample of one, and draws a sweeping conclusion, such as, \\"If I can do it, anyone can!\\" Notice that the same reasoning would apply had he merely bought a winning lottery ticket. \\"I'm a genius for picking 3293927! Those long odds didn't mean a darn thing. I mean, after all, I won didn't I!\\"    Not all success is luck. In some professions, skill matters (for example, if you are a dentist), but luck dominates in others. In the case of the inspiring businessman, consider his population cohort. Where are all the similarly situated people who started out like him and have the same attributes? Are they also rich? Or homeless? Usually you can't find this sort of \\"silent\\" disconfirming evidence. Artistic success provides a perfect illustration. Their \\"failure\\" hides the evidence that would undercut Balzac's \\"success\\" as a uniquely great writer. The evidence is silent, lost in the graveyard of history.     The mind uses many more simplifying schemas that can lead to error. Once people have theories, they seek confirming evidence; this is called \\"confirmation bias.\\" They fall victim to \\"epistemic arrogance,\\" becoming overconfident about their ideas and failing to account for randomness. To make their theories work, people \\"smooth out\\" the \\"jumps\\" in a time series or historical sequence, looking for and finding patterns that are not there. Their conceptual categories will limit what they see; this is called \\"tunneling.\\" They turn to \\"experts\\" for help, but often these expert opinions are no better - and often they are worse - than the \\"insights\\" gained from flipping a coin or hiring a trained chimp to throw darts at the stock listings. Worst of all, people steadily fail to consider \\"black swans,\\" the highly consequential rare events that drive history.    Taleb's style is personal and literary, his heterodox insights are rigorous. This combination makes for a thrilling, disturbing, contentious and unforgettable book on chance and randomness. While Taleb offers strong medicine some readers may find too bitter at times, we prescribe it to anyone who wants a powerful inoculation against gullibility. One of the best non-fiction books of this decade.

B000O178BY|5.0|Let me begin by saying this is not so much of a \\"technical\\" review of the sound of this disc.  No comparison of the disc to others Trent created.  Rather, this is a review based on a more emotive response to the work as (A)rt.  It may sound more like a treatise on What Is Art? but I really do view this disc beyond the realm of simply a collection of songs. <br /> <br />I have to be honest...intially I was not completely taken by the disc. The first 3 songs were NIN but the remainder varied. Capitol G, God Given and In This Twilight were the only ones beyond the 3 that I found appealing. Did I simply not get it? <br /> <br />The very premise that an artist produces art that a \\"fan\\" gravitates to implicitly is so false yet there are some who think art is an EitherOr condition. To this day I don't enjoy The Fragile in its totality. <br /> <br />Art finds it purpose in the subject...not in the artist. When art (B)ecomes for the subject it truly becomes real. The artist is like a frame in which the art can become fused: where does the artist end and the art begin? Is the frame part of the art? My point, it is possible to admire Trent so much that whatever he produces is to tied into (H)im that the art cannot stand on its own. <br /> <br />I am guilty of this from time to time. I found myself loathing me because I was not into the work simply because of my admiration of Trent as an artist. Why? Because the artist discloses a (R)eality that the subject cannot objectify...it is a moment of sharing. It is an intimacy and if the art is not found to be that gateway to (R)eality then there is a feeling as if the relationship is broken or harmed. <br /> <br />I have listed to YZ roughly a dozen times and I have come to accept something from it; something that elevates it as art. The fusion of lyrics to sound is critical. Allowing yourself, as subject, to become open to the emotions of the subject-matter creates a synchronicity. There is a pain to this work that is less narcisistic than Trent's past work. Rather than simply express disdain or anger there is a sense of dissapointment at potential lost. I get the work. I feel the work. <br /> <br />I can fully appreciate why one might not like the album...I was there. There is the condition that you simply don't like the \\"sound\\" or \\"noise\\"...I get that too. Maybe it isn't hard enough. Ok, valid point. What I think this art requires is a vulnerability from the subject. But again, maybe that is simply the blur of the artist and the art.

B0000025L0|5.0|Widely considered one of the two essential jazz bass guitar records (the other being Jaco Pastorious' eponymous debut record, also released in 1976), \\"School Days\\" finds virtuoso Stanley Clarke providing a good indication of what he's made of.  Supported by a fine ensemble (usually Raymond Gomez on guitar, David Sancious on keys and either Gerry Brown or Steve Gadd on drums), Clarke creates a record that is very much a funk bass call to arms.  And certainly as a bassist, I find myself, even years after I've first heard this one, picking my jaw up off the ground (listening to the first 30 seconds of closer \\"Life is Just a Game\\" will do that to you). <br /> <br />One thing immediately noticable about the record is that it's startling diverse, sliding easily from loping funk (\\"School Days\\") to slithering synths (\\"Quiet Afternoon\\"), old school horn-driven funk jazz (\\"Life is Just a Game\\") and even a slice of acoustic calm in the midst of the storm (\\"Desert Song\\", featuring Clarke on an upright and guitarist John McLaughlin on acoustic guitar).  Throughout, the playing is top notch and it maintains itself as engaging. <br /> <br />One point I'd like to make-- this album is screaming for remastering.  The 1990 CD transfer just doesn't cut it.  But this aside, \\"School Days\\" is a classic, a great slice of funk-driven fusion jazz, and for anyone wanting to see blazing chops on a bass guitar, this is where to look.

B00000IL26|5.0|Lee Morgan was one of the most gifted hard bop trumpeters of his or any generation since, and \\"The Sidewinder\\" has long been regarded as his magnum opus. The album's title track has become a significant jazz standard, with generations of budding artists since interpreting it both live and on record. This being one of the premium titles in Blue Note's long list of albums to date, Lee Morgan's \\"The Sidewinder\\" is one of the top-selling jazz albums of all time.<br /><br />Joe Henderson is admirably fantastic on this 1963 recording as is the legendary pianist Barry Harris, both of whom exhibit on here uncanny swinging improvisational backdrops and solos. Henderson underscores here how great an impact and influence John Coltrane was having on artists like himself by this point. But truly it is Lee Morgan, most of all, who stands out far and ahead of the pack on these tracks. \\"Totem Poll\\" is an absolute delight, opening to a wonderful piano-intro from Barry Harris with Lee stepping in shortly.<br /><br />This Rudy Van Gelder Edition comes with 24-bit remastering done by Rudy himself, and the sound quality and clarity is just right throughout. This is one of the most celebrated jazz albums for as long as anyone can remember, a must have for everyone establishing a jazz collection for themselves. You also get an alternate take of \\"Totem Pole\\", so buy \\"The Sidewinder\\" today! A five-star album if ever there was one.<br /><br />Personnel:<br /><br />Lee Morgan (trumpet)<br /><br />Joe Henderson (tenor sax)<br /><br />Barry Harris (piano)<br /><br />Bob Cranshaw (bass)<br /><br />Billy Higgins (drums)<br /><br />Producer: Alfred Lion<br /><br />Label: Blue Note<br /><br />Recorded: December 21, 1963<br /><br />Location: Rudy Van Gelder Studio, Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey<br /><br />Edition: The Rudy Van Gelder Edition series<br /><br />Remastering: 24-bit
B000NVIXFK|4.0|It seems that when a band only puts out a new album every 5 years or so, fans have much higher expectations.  After all, if the album sucks, you have to wait another 5 long years for another one...unlike the 70s and 80s, when you could count on a new Rush album every year or so, so you didn't have long to wait if you didn't like the most current one.  Plus, as they get older and older, you have to wonder how many more albums they will make...the arrival of a new Rush album these days is a treat, as I don't feel they really have anything left to prove.  They seem to be in the \\"I love doing this\\" mode.  We all know they are great, so why give them such a hard time if the album isn't Moving Pictures II?  Most popular doesn't always mean best.  Those kinds of things are usually based on individual nostalga rather than actual musical content. <br /> <br />That said, I don't think \\"Snakes & Arrows\\" is a great album, but neither is it a bad one.  It's the typical Rush album - 3/4 of the songs are really good, and the other 1/4 are kind of okay.  They only have a few albums that I feel are truly great from start to finish (Permanent Waves, Power Windows, Moving Pictures & Vapor Trails fall into this category for me, personally).  And as usual, the album is definitely different from what they've done before.  Any Rush fan should know by now (even those who can't get past Moving Pictures) that they are masters at trying different styles and changing up their sound as the times change without completely alienating their fan base.  The fact that basically all their albums after MP have still gone Gold should be proof enough of that.  So the new elements on S&A (like the pervasive acoustic guitar throughout) shouldn't surprise anyone. <br /> <br />The only way I can describe S&A is that it's \\"mellow.\\"  It's very laid back compared to their previous works and the influences of the Feedback EP they did recently are very evident here.  The return to their 70s sound that the producer remarked on a while back refers more to that feel, I think, than the technical and 10 minute songs they used to do.  Only a few songs on this album have any urgency at all.  It's definitely different and upon the first few listens I wasn't impressed, but many of the songs are growing on me. <br /> <br />I'm not going to do a track by track review, but my favorites by far are <br /> <br />\\"Armor and Sword\\" - best lyrics on the album, lot of musical depth <br /> <br />\\"The Larger Bowl\\" - simple but meaningful lyrics with a good tune; if this had been released back in the 70s it would probably be a live staple such as \\"Closer to the Heart\\" <br /> <br />\\"The Main Monkey Business\\" - \\"YYZ\\" obviously is the definitive Rush instrumental, but I put this in a 2nd place tie with \\"Leave That Thing Alone\\" and \\"La Villa Strangiato\\"; it just has an awesome groove and should be good live <br /> <br />The album kind of dies out around the last 3 songs, which are the sketchy ones.  \\"Malignant Narcissism\\" seems like a complete afterthought and thrown on the album for fun.  \\"We Hold On\\" is my least favorite song on the album and not a very good song to end with...it just doesn't have the feeling that a closer like \\"Available Light\\" or \\"Vital Signs\\" has.  Only a handful of Rush albums have really good closing songs, in my opinion. <br /> <br />In the end, if you like any of their material from \\"Presto\\" forward, then you'll definitely like this.  There are gems on every Rush album, and they are all worth buying, even this one. <br />

1400063515|5.0|2007 is only 1/3 done, but the year's best business book is already clear. Taleb's book is about black swans---highly improbable events that have a big impact on the world. Think 9/11, the East Asian crash of 1997, or the collapse of the Soviet Empire. Taleb's claim is that there are so many potential black swans that even though each one is very improbable, one or another hits on a regular basis. We are blind to the black swans ahead of time because each is unlikely. More importantly we are blind after the fact because we learn about the details of the black swan that actually hit rather than thinking about all the thousands that could have hit and did not.  <br /> <br />Taleb is a scholar and an iconoclast, skewering many sacred cows while explaining his claims and backing up his ideas. Plus this book is a lot of  fun to read.

B000O178BY|3.0|Where to begin.    Lets start with `With teeth'. WT defiantly was lacking right from the get go. In retrospect, WT was the most commercial rock-n-roll album that NIN dangled in front of my drooling ravenous face that really just left a bad taste in my mouth.  Despite this sad delivery, I supported and swallowed the record since I believed that a less compelling album from NIN is still better than 90% [...]that's out there now.      what does this say about year zero?  Well two wrongs don't make a right.  If with teeth was a typical rock-n-roll album that marked the complete opposite of the nail's industrial signature, then year zero went too far to achieve the absolute contrary.  At times it's simply too noisy to the point where it's just unwarranted and undesirable.  Every single song seems to begin with the exact same loopy drum beat, and any decent guitar, or distinct sound effect that could give the song any kind of possible substance can barely breath underneath the overwhelming, drowning, out-of-place noise. No real build up to any song. In a weird way this sounds like a b-list remix album that was intended as half-a** halo to tide us over until the real thing is finalized to perfection.  One of my favorite things about the pre-WT era was the balance that NIN would achieve with the tactful placement of noise in what would otherwise be a trivial rock song and transforming it into an industrial masterpiece of fury. This era seems to no longer exist.  But only because it's The Nails, do I condone the utter lack of creativity that has transpired into what could very well be a complete let down.     With all this said Ido believe that it is probably too early to really bash the album since music can take many months to grow on you.  I distinctly remember being very disappointed with 'lateralus' when it first came out truly believing that Tool finally lost their charm.  It wasn't till many months of careful analysis of the album that I realized that it is indeed their undisputed masterpiece.  Though I don't see this type of a result surfacing in YZ, I do believe that the album has potential and will give off a different feel once it has had time to nest itself in the listening rotation.     I will also mention that I don't want to steer people away from this album by any means, for this is a must-have for any true NIN fan and I do believe that everybody in essence is their own critic in the end, and only when you listen for your self will you actualize your own true thoughts about this piece of work.  Let us hope that we can still get something out of Year Zero.

B000NVIXFK|4.0|It's surprising the negative responses that claim this CD isn't any different than [insert least favorite CD here].  Neil had described the work as \\"organic\\" when he was listening to it taking shape and it wasn't apparent until I heard this.  I'd probably use that word to describe the relationship between music and lyrics that seems very different this CD. <br /> <br />Usually I've always felt that the music and lyrics complemented each other perfectly, it a very structured and semi-predictable way.  Even when the band is playing odd time signatures and dancing all over the fretboard and drumkit the lyrics still seem confined to a predictable structure.  This is not the case with this CD. <br /> <br />Another reviewer commented that the songs sounded disjuncted and \\"randomized\\" together and I wouldn't say that's completely inaccurate.  I'll be the first to admit I'm not the most objective having been a fan since Permanent Waves and enjoying almost everything they've put out other than Roll the Bones and Presto.  The rhyming doesn't seem to be as much a concern for Neil as it was in the past or there isn't as much work in rewrites.  All that being said, there's plenty of music out there with lyrics that don't rhyme at all (Pearl Jam for instance) and it's still great stuff. <br /> <br />There are some songs where it does sound forced, vocal melodies jammed together with lyrics simply because they had nowhere else to go I assume.  There are some songs on this CD I just can't make it through -- The Larger Bowl, Spindrift -- because of this very problem.   <br /> <br />But I LOVE the guitar sound on this CD.  It doesn't suffer from Alex's \\"less is more\\" phase (Presto, Roll the Bones) and doesn't suffer the \\"more is more\\" phase (Hold Your Fire).  It's BIG, it's LOUD, it's tasty, meaty, layered, effectified, and probably Alex's best guitar sound since 2112 or Hemispheres.  However, if you're looking for tasty licks and blazing solos this is not the CD to find them on.  Sure, there's some sweet bluesy licks and huge panning volume swells but nothing noteworthy in the solo department.  Even the instrumentals. <br /> <br />I'd also add that the bass and drums sound good.  Not great.  Not that Rickenbacker crunch or the Steinberger pop or even the Wal [fill in a word for that sound].  It's ok, even tasty at times (Malignant Narcissism) but I'm getting the feeling these days that Geddy is spending more time layering his vocals and concentrating there then on his playing.  Personally I'm disappointed since I whine for his playing constantly and wish he could hit those notes of his youth, but it's not awful. <br /> <br />The drums sound plain at times.  Yes, I will sound like a \\"old Rush\\" fan when I say things like how I miss Neil's hi-hat out of nowhere on the backbeat things he would do. They do make a slight appearance on Good News First but very very slightly.  It's still solid drumming IMHO, but the \\"sound\\" of the drums doesn't seem as brilliant or impact-oriented as even Vapor Trails.  I'm left to wonder what happened there. <br /> <br />So after all that why 4 stars?  It's not because I'm a fan, honest.  I really didn't like Vapor Trails that much and said so.  I think some of their albums just sucked (Presto and Roll the Bones).  I admit, I have a weakness for guitar and this one just sounds guitariffic.  That has a lot to do with it.  But lyricially I like it.  Even if I don't think the lyrics fit the song as well as previous works, so what?  It's different.  I've been in a rut with Rush these days, thinking \\"Man, I'm tired of Rush...I guess I'll pop in some more SB or Porcupine Tree, etc\\" but this CD was different enough that I could say \\"Wow, this sounds different enough that I don't feel like I'm listening to the same old Rush\\" and yet it still has the odd time signatures and though provoking lyrics prog rock is supposed to be all about. <br /> <br />Best songs: Armor and Sword, Workin' Them Angels, Malignant Narcissism

B00000272N|5.0|Four young men from Seattle were in the music business to take over the airwaves with their metal-grunge style and sound. They sold millions upon millions of records in their illustrious career, and it began with a debut full of hard metal blues, a little boogie, and impassioned performances. This young band was known as Alice In Chains and the debut album I'm speaking about is the maelstrom known as FACELIFT. Brimming with enough angst to kick a cow from here to Timbuktu, FACELIFT was heavy on metal and classic rock styles, with an undercurrent of grunge lying underneath it all. Honestly, this is the heaviest album next to DIRT that Alice In Chains ever made.     There are two main ingredients here that make this album sizzle hotter than a firecracker on the 4th of July: Layne Staley's unbelievably amazing and caterwaul vocal performance, and Jerry Cantrell's powerful metal riffs and rip-roaring solos. But, you cannot count out the great rhythm section of bassist Mike Starr and drummer Sean Kinney, who hold their own ever so capably underneath the two stalwarts and they are important pieces themselves.     \\"We Die Young\\" is a short burst of aggro-grunge that fires at you at 100 miles per hour, with Cantrell's razor-sharp riffing and Layne Staley's menacing voice growling lines like \\"scary's on the wall/scary's on his way/watch where you spit/i'd advise you wait until it's over\\". It brims full of anger yet the chorus shines and pummels at your face. Then \\"Man In The Box\\" rips open the door with it's heavier-than-thou grunge riff and Staley's stated scream of \\"Feed my eyes!\\". It became a staple on radio thanks to it's catchy rhythm and stellar musicianship, and one hell of a solo by Jerry Cantrell. \\"Sea of Sorrow\\" is damn near classic itself, featuring a great chorus between Staley and Cantrell, and yet another great solo by Cantrell, with Kinney and Starr keeping steady pace. Then we dip into the creepy crawl of \\"Bleed The Freak\\", again with Staley turning in another great vocal turn, and even the slightly melodic \\"I Can't Remember\\" thunders and growls with a quiet intensity lying underneath. Then comes a track like \\"Love, Hate, Love\\", which is a chilling tale over Staley's lamenting and musing about doing a horrible thing to his lover, all the while Cantrell shines one of his best solos on the album, and Staley turns in probably the most gut-wrenching vocal performance on the album, especially when he growls in a terrifying scream \\"Love! Hate! Love!\\" The chugging dinosaur riffs of \\"It Ain't Like That\\" hammer home with a precision of a clock. Then things start to get a little jangly with the boogie-metal of \\"Put You Down\\" and \\"I Know Somethin' (Bout You)\\", both of which are very damn catchy numbers. It all comes to a close with \\"Real Thing\\", which ends the album on a bluesy note, and a crashing finale featuring Layne coughing, most likely for show and not for real.     So after you listen all the way through FACELIFT's 12 tracks, you'll find yourself recovering like a boy who's recovering from a swift and hard punch. That's how I can describe FACELIFT...it's more like a good punch in the face that will leave a little blood in its aftermath yet shines on because it's determined to leave a lasting impression on you. And by all accounts, FACELIFT leaves a big impression from it's stormy brew of grunge metallic, alternative darkness.

B000NVIXFK|4.0|I gave this album a low review because it didn't meet my expectations...it was far at the time but now I'm reconsidering it.    Snakes and Arrows is a serious departure for Rush, one that may launch a new phase for \\"the boys\\"    Several of songs have very loose instrumentals that lead me to think that Rush may be changing the way they handle live performances.  We're used to Rush being a band who slavishly attempts to recreate the studio sound live.    Snakes and Arrows has a different sound, one where the instrumental breaks are pretty unstructured.  By that I mean guitar solos are sparse with Geddy and Neil largely driving the action.  Listen to \\"Fry Cry\\" for a perfect example of what I am talking about.  Alex lets the guitars open up more on the instrumentals but even they have a different quality to them.    Dare I say, a \\"jam\\" quality.    If this is the path that Rush is taking it's a bold gambit but one I'm willing to support.  With their rich back catalog, there are dozens of songs that are open to reinterpretation and for the fans that stick with it then it will be a fascinating experience.    And if I'm right then Snakes and Arrows wasn't a disappointment.   It is a master stroke that let a 40 year old band redefine itself in a flash with a jam band album.                             OLD REVIEW:  in creating boring, self-derivative music.    I have ben listening to Rush since Moving Pictures and have enjoyed the bands evolution as they incorporated various musical styles into their own.    My love of the band's music has been tested in recent years as the band churned out more AOR friendly tracks- for every \\"Driven\\" there was a \\"Time and Motion\\" or \\"Speed of Love\\"- songs that felt like filler or worse, songs that felt like they were generated by a \\"random Rush song\\" program.    That trend was broken somewhat by the band's most recent original studio effort, Vapor Trails in which the boys really cranked things up and out out an interesting album full of hooks, drive and creativity.    Snakes and Arrows was said to be a return to roots with song constructions and guitar tones reminiscent of the band's art-rock years of [roughly] 1977-1980.    Based on my opinion of Vapor Trails and the anticipation of a return to a very creative, dynamic sound I had high hopes for Snakes and Arrows.    \\"Far Cry\\", the album's opening track, should have served as a warning.  The opening did sound as if it was lifted from a studio session from Hemispheres, but soon devolved into the formulaic Rush sound- in this case the song sounded like a Counterparts outtake.    The experience of listening to Snakes and Arrows quickly went downhill after that.  After listening to the first four tracks I realized I had the \\"Son of Test For Echo\\" in my CD player.    Three general observations about the album:  1) Where are the hooks?  Nothing grabbed me like the bridge of \\"The Trees\\" or opening riff of \\"Secret Touch\\".     2) The songs plod along with no tricky changes in tempo or time signature.  There are songs like \\"The Way the Wind Blows\\" where the band mixes up tempo and dynamics a bit but it ends up sounding like the AOR formula Rush- rock a little, then let off and go acoustic- you know, like in \\"Nobody's Hero\\".    Sad that now when the band has 70+ minutes to work with instead of the 40 minutes afforded by vinyl they produce a bunch of samey-feeling four to six minute songs instead of a twenty minute opus where they can really develop some ideas.      3) Some of the lyrics are almost embarrassingly earnest.  I won't quote them out of context [that's unfair] but you'd know them if heard them.  Neil Peart has always been capable of writing some groaners but I could often ignore them because the music carried the song.  That's not the case on this record.    If I thought Rush was mailing it in, I would have given this one star but I've never doubted the effort or talent of the band.  This album just didn't click and the results are very disappointingbased on the hype, which had me thinking it was a \\"return to the future\\".      For completists and people who like the Test For Echo / AOR-sounding Rush only.
B000002J1S|5.0|This is a terrific album and the whole experience has already been thoroughly documented in these reviews.  Top-notch musicianship, daring lyrics, addictive hooks, innovative concept, the whole bit.<br /><br />I've read lots of speculation about The Lamb's plot, but I think one potential theory has been overlooked.  I believe it's given away in the second verse of the first song on the album:<br /><br />... Metal motion comes in bursts,<br />But the gas station can quench that thirst<br />Suspension cracked on unmade road<br />The truckers eyes read Overload<br />And out of the subway,<br />Rael Imperial Aerosol Kid<br />Exits into daylight, spraygun hid,<br />And the lamb lies down on Broadway<br /><br />A few seconds after the introduction of Rael, I believe he's killed by this out of control truck with cracked suspension careening out from an alleyway, and lying dead on Broadway his soul is released and sent on this quest through some sort of \\"purgatory\\" (?).  The album documents Rael's path to salvation with reflections on society, his own life and adventures in the afterlife.  Rael has become the sacrificial lamb of societal decay, and in the end he finally does right by regaining his own lost love of self and others - at last discovering the \\"it.\\" that life and true compassion are made of.<br /><br />One of the most amazing aspects of this album is that it allows a unique experience for each listener.  The story lends itself to endless speculation and countless interpretations so it never really gets old.  The lyrics are just vague enough and the music layered enough to constantly re-discover it.  Once you \\"get it\\" it will haunt you for a very long time.  Simply an amazing accomplishment.<br /><br />Buy it, listen to it, listen to it five more times, then try to put it down.  I dare you.

B000NVIXFK|3.0|Let me preface the following comments by first saying that I LOVE Rush, for the same reasons everyone else here probably does. B00005JOFQ|5.0|I saw \\"Brokeback Mountain\\" a little over a year ago when it was playing in the theaters. It's still on my mind. This has to be one of the best movies I've ever seen. Absolutely stunning.<br /><br />\\"Brokeback Mountain\\" is a tragic love story, and it's tragic on every scale. It was set largely in rustic and scenic Wyoming (actually, Alberta) and it unfolded as two young men met as employees of a local rancher. Their task was to care for a herd of sheep on Brokeback Mountain over the summer months. They gradually became friends and then \\"special friends.\\" At the end of the summer, they parted and went on with their lives including getting married and raising families. The experience of Brokeback Mountain, however, proved too strong and they gradually started getting back together again, and again. The result was an aching love story and a growing tragedy for the men, their families and all concerned. The story riveted my attention and was painful to watch. My girlfriend and I left the theater and we couldn't talk. We were both choked up by the emotional impact. We discussed it for the next several months, however. The movie was that powerful.<br /><br />Everyone associated with this film should get an award of some kind. The director gently reached out and grabbed hold of the audiences' attention. He then allowed the tragic story to unfold amid a spendid scenic backdrop and accompanied by wonderful music. In watching it, you feel as if you're a part of the story, or at least a fly on the wall. This film is amazing and very powerful. View it, by all means. If the subject matter bothers you, don't buy and complain. This film deserves a lot more respect than some of the coarse remarks in certain viewer reviews.

To me this song remains fresh even after thousands of listens. <br /> <br />Emerson, Lake and Palmer was never able to come up with another album as enjoyable as this one, though honestly they did come close with their next album.  Buy this one first, then the second one.

B000HT386M|2.0|They keep letting this guy (Adam Sandler) make movies; most likely because audiences flock to see most of his stuff, as was the case with \\"Click\\" (2006). I'm not going to go into a rant about the sophistication level of those who patronize their local multi-plexus. Suffice it to say that \\"Click\\" is as good as at least half the big-budget ($70 Million) stuff that is being released to the mainstream public. It raked in some serious cash last July. <br /> <br />Apparently Sadler has a thing for Frank Capra, as this is his second attempt to remake a Capra classic (insert \\"Mr. Deeds Goes to Town\\"). \\"Click\\" is Sandler's take on \\"It's a Wonderful Life\\" (1946). At least I assume the Jimmy Stewart classic was what they were aiming at because the end result seems more of a blend of \\"Scrooged\\" and \\"Being There\\". \\"Click\\" is probably Sandler's all-time best performance; in the style of and equal in quality to a good Tim Allen performance. He is assisted by a supporting cast of recognizable actors; Henry Winkler, Julie Kavner, Christopher Walken, David Hasselhoff, and Sean Astin. There is also a brief appearance by Jack Nicholson's daughter Lorraine, who looks amazingly like Jack back in his \\"Easy Rider\\" days; this is actually kind of scary. <br /> <br />Kate Beckinsale has the same role that Winona Ryder had in Mr. Deeds. While neither of them rank up there with Jean Arthur (the heroine in both Capra classics) they are still two of the best actresses out there today. I'm assuming both were very well paid because the scripts offer little opportunity for either to showcase their considerable acting skills. In fact the mismatch between talent and opportunity produces a strange discordance in both films. This might be one of those cases where a less talented performer would have been a better fit.  <br /> <br />George Bailey (and Scrooge) had an attitude adjustment after being granted visions of the past and the future by his guardian angel. Michael Newman's (Sandler) angel (Walken), who works in the local Bed, Bath and Beyond store, gives him a television remote control that he can click whenever he wants to fast-forward his life past the parts that are annoying distractions to his workaholic aspirations. At first this seems like a wonderful device as he can dispense with the family interactions that complicate his life. But Michael soon discovers that the device programs itself and shifts him further and further into the future. The remote can also freeze a scene, mute the sound, and select past scenes from his life; but the film mostly concentrates on its fast-forwarding function. <br /> <br />\\"Click\\" is technically a comedy and apparently some find a lot to laugh about. There are some funny moments early in the production but I found the humor to be in short supply for most of the story. <br /> <br />Ultimately \\"Click\\" has a \\"Groundhog Day\\" sort of theme. That in tuning out much of what life has to offer we miss life itself. Since this cold detached way of living is what most of us do (at least to some degree) it tends to undermine any comic quality the film might have. Of course unless your taste in comedy runs to Sandler's usual focus on bodily functions it doesn't take much to do this anyway.  <br /> <br />Inexplicably, even at his most detached, patient and accepting people surround Michael. His wife (Beckinsale), his parents (Winkler and Kavner), and his children continue to love him despite the absence of any lovable qualities. Similar to those who love this film. <br /> <br />Then again, what do I know? I'm only a child.

A renewed Rush appperared in 2002 with Vapor Trails which again was something a little different as it was a lot heavier sounding and had no guitar solo's, not one? While Vapor Trails had some really good spots, it like many other of the Rush offerings of late is lacking something. It's hard to describe, but it just seems like the magic is gone. That special something just isn't their anymore!<br /><br />So here we are a few years later with yet another Rush offering on the table. Is this cd what we've come to expect from this great band? Well the answer is yes and no! There are some very cool parts found on the lastest disc, however after a few spins it really hasn't grabbed a hold of me like the older stuff does. I find it's lacking true staying power. This cd is a good listen, but will I be listening to it or say some other Rush cd's I have in say a month or two. The answer is, I'll probably be back listeing to those classic Rush offerings as they seem to have more to offer in my honest opinion.<br /><br />So I have to give it a 3 as I was really hoping for a more interesting mix of tunes.

B00005ATZT|5.0|Movies based on television shows are frustrating for the creative team behind the adaptation and often prove to be somewhat hit and miss.  The reason is because in a TV show the writer/director gets to spread his/her story over the course of multiple episodes or even an entire season.  In a movie you only get an average of 2 hours to get your story out, which can cause problems when adapting a television series, whether it be a long-running or short lived show, for theaters because you just don't have the luxury of time.  There have been some successful adaptations, \\"Starsky & Hutch\\", `Star Trek', `Mission: Impossible', and even `Charlie's Angels' (though I didn't care for either incarnation of the franchise), along with the success there have been those that failed \\"The Avengers\\" was lackluster, and \\"The Dukes of Hazzard\\" was the most recent, and possibly the worst adaptation I have seen in a long while.  In 1993, Warner Brothers felt the calling to try their collective hand at an adaptation, and their choice was the hit TV series \\"The Fugitive\\".  To assist in the success of their endeavor the WB enlisted top-notch, veteran acting talents Harrison Ford and Tommy Lee Jones, and hired director Andrew Davis hot off his highly successful submarine action film, \\"Under Siege\\". <br /> <br />\\"The Fugitive\\" tells the story of Dr. Richard Kimble (Harrison Ford), who after a charity event arrives home to find an intruder in his house and his wife murdered.  After fighting off the intruder, Kimble alerts the police, and upon their arrival Kimble is surprised by the fact that he is arrested for the murder of his own wife.  After being found guilty at his trial and sentenced to prison, the prison bus Kimble is being transported by crashes in front of an oncoming train.  After being freed by a correctional officer to assist with the other prisoners, Dr. Kimble flees in hopes of tracking down the one-armed murderer and proving his innocence.  However, hot on Richard's trail is a relentless U.S. Marshal, Sam Gerard (Tommy Lee Jones), and his team of deputies, who will stop at nothing until their man is caught.  Let the chase begin! <br /> <br />Clearly the executives at Warner Brothers made an excellent decision to make this adaptation, and managed to find the perfect cast, writer, and director to pull it off.  The cast, led by Harrison Ford (an actor that delivers a terrific performance every time) and Tommy Lee Jones (who was great in this role and was rewarded with the Oscar for Best Supporting Actor), all give excellent performances, fleshing out each individual character and making the movie believable and real to the audience.  The story by David Twohy (\\"Pitch Black\\" and \\"The Chronicles of Riddick\\") is full of twists and turns, with riveting drama and action along with bits of comedy sprinkled about to lighten things up just a bit.  The direction of Andrew Davis, though not flashy by any means, delivers a very tight, well-paced manhunt movie that keeps the audience fully engrossed from start to finish, even though they already have a pretty good guess what the outcome will be, based on the source material. <br /> <br />As I stated earlier some adaptations of TV shows to movies work out well and some don't, and the reasons generally stem from what I pointed out in the beginning of this review, but sometimes the results may vary depending on how committed to the project the cast/crew and the studio are.  It's nice to see that for \\"The Fugitive\\" all parties involved in the making of this picture gave their best, and the fruits of the labor paid off big time, making this movie one of the best TV series adaptations to ever be made. <br /> <br />\\"The Fugitive\\" is rated PG-13 for violence and language.

B000NVIXFK|5.0|Music is HIGHLY subjective... that's a given.  You can either feel enthusiastic, lukewarm, or dissapointed about Rush's latest effort. 'Progressive rock', after all, partially encompasses this view of change and moving forward, as well as the requisite prog style of music tempo and time signature changes.  Anywho, to my middle-aged ears, 'Snakes & Arrows' is truly excellent and beautiful, with LOTS of passion, texture, and mastery, which can only be the creation of a veteran, respected, world-class band like RUSH.  The lyrics are 'vintage Peart' and even 'darker' than usual this time around, questioning faith and presumably the existence of 'God' (or at least a benevolent 'God') at various points throughout.  Can you blame or fault him?!  Man is 'laid bare' to fend for himself in an unpredictable, often cruel, vexing world subject to its vagaries and hardships (Peart knows this in 'real life', given the beyond cruel, tragic loss of his daughter and wife)!  In summation of this short review, I must also comment on the excellent production and sonics of this epic and masterful CD, which is first rate.  They did a SUPERB recording and mastering job, and it shows especially on a killer high end, high resolution audio system (I run McIntosh gear and Magneplanar speakers, as an example).  LONG LIVE RUSH!  THANK YOU, GEDDY, ALEX, AND NEIL.
0226752275|5.0|Frankenstein is a great work, though one that has consistently been underrated<br />and misrepresented. Frankenstein is, in the words of Donald H. Reiman, \\"the<br />most seminal literary work of the Romantic period\\". It is a work of profound<br />and radical ideas, written in poetically powerful prose. Frankenstein is not<br />really a gothic novel, although its author sometimes employs gothic<br />conventions and language, and even spoofs them. Rather, Frankenstein is an<br />enduring myth, a novel of ideas, and above all, a moral allegory about the<br />evil effects of intolerance and prejudice, ostracism and alienation, both to<br />the victims of intolerance and to society at large.<br />Since there are some good reviews here, I'll concentrate on this<br />particular edition -- the Chicago edition edited by James Rieger.<br />This is one of the two best editions of Frankenstein available (the other<br />being the Norton Critical edition). Most importantly, this is<br />the original 1818 edition, rather than the inferior, bowdlerized 1831<br />edition -- which is the most common, and the only one that was available for<br />well over a century. James Rieger was the first editor to make the case for the<br />superiority of the 1818 edition, and he did so convincingly enough that almost all<br />scholars of English Romanticism now prefer the 1818 edition.  Rieger took a lot<br />of flak from feminist academics for asserting that Percy Bysshe Shelley was,<br />at the very least, a minor collaborator.  In my considered opinion, Shelley was the primary author, and Mary Shelley was merely his secretary.<br />The appendices in this edition include the full text of John William Polidori's<br />story, \\"The Vampyre: A Tale\\" and Byron's brief fragment of a vampire story.<br />Rieger's comments on the 1831 Introduction (written ostensibly by Mary, but with<br />much help from her father, William Godwin) are perceptive.<br />Please check out my own book, The Man Who Wrote Frankenstein, which<br />makes the case that Frankenstein was really written by Percy Bysshe Shelley,<br />one of the greatest poets in the English language.,  one of the greatest poets in the English language.

And then on other albums the music sounded forced and disjoint (Tales from the Topographic Oceans, Tormato). <br /> <br />What's Wrong with me? <br /> <br />I understand that Rush put a lot of effort and time into this album.  So why don't I appreciate it?  I've come to two conclusions.  1) They are pursuing direction that just don't please me anymore.  2) They have been around music so much that they have evolved to a higher level a musical patterns that the lay person may have trouble relating too. <br /> <br />Do I just take the narrow nostalgic view? <br /> <br />I think some people are too ready to dismiss negative reviewers as being stuck in a nostalgic \\"hit\\" period. <br /> <br />Before you categorize me as such keep this in mind: <br />1) I love just about everything Rush has done between Hemispheresand Counterparts. <br />2) I feel like they have been losing me a little bit more with each release starting with Test for Echo. <br /> <br />In conclusion, I'm happy that some people are seeing some really cool creative stuff on this new album, Snakes and Arrows. <br /> <br />As for me, its even hard to listen to.  Well, Rush has been one of the best musical experiences for me in my life while the good times lasted. <br />

B000NVIXFK|4.0|To begin with, let me say that the sound of Snakes & Arrows is fantastic.  The mastering process seems to have been improved 100% since Vapor Trails in 2002.  Generally the sound is thick and crisp.  In terms of recording quality I think that it is the best sounding Rush album that there has ever been.  Stylistically it is a hard rock album, probably the \\"hardest\\" record that Rush has made in a long time.  The sound is very textured, thick and layered with lots of interesting sounds. <br /> <br />Musically they seem to want to avoid creating or playing anything that is too obvious or conventional.  After 30+ years of making music I can see how the typical rock song would be boring for these master musicians.  There is very little on this record that is \\"catchy\\" on the first few listens and sometimes a single song doesn't seem to hold itself together well, like the person who wrote the verse was working in a different room from the person who wrote the chorus.  The melodies are unusual and will require some effort from casual listeners to appreciate.  Some listeners may simply reject this music as non-melodic nonsense or noise, but as a Rush fan, I hope that this record is like a good piece of modern art, the more you examine it, the more fascinating it becomes.  There are some great time signature changes in the song \\"Workin' Them Angels\\" and I really enjoy some parts of some of the songs.   <br /> <br />Lyrically the record is rather dark and sad with themes of determinism and resignation in the face of all the evils of the world.  They went from \\"I will choose freewill\\" in 1981 to \\"we can only grow the way the wind blows - we can only bow to the here and now or be broken down blow by blow.\\"  This is not a record that I would want to listen to over and over without having some more positive material to listen to on the side.  For me this is not a fault of the album, and I appreciate Neil Peart's willingness to honestly express all aspects of life, the good and thebad.  Perhaps this change is a function of maturity and a recognition that eventually innocence is lost the real world must be looked squarely in the eyes.  In any case these lyrics are more profound and heartfelt than anything recently on the radio or MTV.  Even with this lyrical aspect of the record, Neil Peart still avoids the silly \\"drowning in pools of black despair\\" stereotype of modern rock music.  I get the feeling that he simply wrote down what he was feeling about certain things in this world and I appreciate that honesty.  There might be some really positive messages here, but with the serious, heavy and ponderous sound of the album- it just feels sad. <br /> <br />In summary, this record may not appeal to everyone, but if you are interested in progressive rock music and are willing to expend a little effort in listening to this album it might be worth your time.  Personally, I haven't made up my mind yet, but I'm trying to like it. <br />
B000MRAAJM|5.0|Whether or not you enjoy or appreciate nature documentaries, I cannot imagine someone not enjoying this series. It's simply the best way to show off your new HD TV and HD-DVD or Blu-Ray system. The picture is excellent, the sound is great, and the documentary itself will likely go down as the greatest nature documentary of all time. <br /> <br />It should be noted that this set is the BBC version of the series, and is narrated by David Attenborough. In the U.S., where I watched the show on the Discovery channel, it was narrated by Sigourney Weaver. Weaver's narration is certainly adequate, accurate, and perfectly serviceable. She only occasionally mispronounced a few words that most people wouldn't recognize anyway. However, I find that I generally prefer Attenborough's version. It's also worth noting that these boxed versions come with slightly differently edited versions of the shows from their televised versions (i.e., extended, with significantly more material per episode). <br /> <br />From a scientific perspective, for the most part the series sticks to facts rather than making moral judgements or stating personal opinion. Thankfully, the editors and producers usually let nature speak for itself, which is powerful enough on its own. <br /> <br />The series contains a lot of eye candy, but there is a significant proportion of it that contains never-before-seen behavior and it's all captured in high definition. If you're looking for something different to show off your HD TV, you could do much worse than this.

B000NVIXFK|3.0|After Vapor Trails, which was nothing short of masterful and incredibly powerful, one of the greatest albums ever, I should have known Rush would come out with something less spectacular. Don't get me wrong, for any other group, Snakes and Arrows is a masterpiece. For Rush, it's mediocre. Like Roll the Bones, it starts out with a bang, with a catchy, driven masterpiece in Far Cry (see Dreamline from Roll the Bones), then turns into a bunch of mid-tempo, mellower songs, right until the end, again, like Roll the Bones. Neil's lyrics really save this outing, as the music is not all that inspired on this release, but the lyrics are thought-provoking and in some places almost controversial (such as the subtle attacks on religion). All in all, a mixed bag. I miss the power of Vapor Trails. I was hoping they would continue exploring that direction. Rush has already done this album.

B000NVIXFK|4.0|2007 has been and will be a great year for new releases, and this disc is right there with the best of them. The songs on \\"Snakes and Arrows\\" are fun, catchy, and well thought out. Plenty of rocking tunes, the three instrumentals are great, a tiny bit of the blues, softer acoustic passages - something for everyone. Geddy's voice is smooth and his bass lines growl with fire and passion, Alex's playing gets better with age and there are plenty of tasty guitar riffs, and Neil's drumming is classy, never overplaying but always right where he should be. There are no keyboards on this disc and I do miss them a bit. Nevertheless, after 33 years of making music (I believe this is their nineteenth studio record) it's amazing that Rush still creates a quality of music this incredible with all the original members, less the drummer from the first album. How many bands accomplish this? Rock on Rush!
B000NVIXFK|4.0|I like to think of Rush albums like moods.  A particular moment in time.  Never the same twice.  Most times I get a new Rush album and crank quickly through all the tracks and ponder.  Some songs hook me right off the bat but others take more time to settle in.  Never once have I hated a song.  They are all different. Thats what makes it good, special.  I'm someone who's been there from the beginning.  I've listened to everything at least a thousand times.  Sometimes I wonder why I listen to Rush so much.  I think it's because it's always different and each album/song puts me in a different frame of mind and a different mood.  I've had this album for about 12 hours now and I'm already hooked.  I really think it sounds great technically and has a lot of new musical feeling.  You will drift through some bluesy riffs, country sounding solos, sections of earthy acoustic guitar (nashville tuned, not 12 string) and mic'ed overdriven amps. Can we move on after 20+ years?  As someone who owns all the albums and even loves the much maligned Presto, Power Windows and Hold Your Fire, I now have something new to love.  It's different, as it should be.  Thanks Rush for something totally new. See you in Boston!

The combo disc has been a controversial issue mainly because many current HD players have issues to play them correctly. Make sure you have the latest firmware on your  HD DVD player.This is the version to own for collectors.

B000N3SRRC|4.0|I suppose after Clutch made three straight records which were consistently amazing through and through (Pure Rock Fury, Blast Tyrant, Robot Hive/Exodus), at some point there has to come a let down.  Every band has a creative genius mode, and these guys were locked in for those glorious records.  I'm glad we Gearheads were along for the ride.  Which is not to say that From Beale Street to Oblivion is a bad record, it's great.  It has everything we've come to expect - great lyrics, great riffs, and great instrumental performances.  It is however, missing that little bit of magic oomph that has brought the last three full lengths 5 star status and nearly universal acclaim.   <br /> <br />Let's start with what is right on this record.  Neil's vocals continue to improve with age, and his wit is as keen as ever.  The best lyricist in rock today (perhaps ever) does not let up on this record.  His stories never fail to entertain, his knowledge, insights and comic timing are once again flawless, and, as ususal there are a half dozen turns of phrase that just make you say WOW, I wish I'd thought of that.  His singing is great, though it is not quite as perfect as on Robot Hive and Blast Tyrant, where he had a chance to really move the listener with some deep, goose bump inducing moments.  I find none of those here - save perhaps the creative mix/match semi cover \\"Electric Worry\\" (which finds Clutch interestingly mixing a Mississippi Fred McDowell song with some new lyrics and arrangements).  In the up and down history of white blues that is rock and roll, I don't know if anyone has ever captured the true essence of the vocal blues like Neil Fallon.  You can just FEEL it.  Elsewhere, JP's drumming is as crisp and imaginative as ever, and the rest of the band kicks as usual.  So what makes this a four star record, a very good but not great release?  It's the riffs, stupid!  For a band that hangs its hat on the riff as much as Clutch, riff-wise this is one of their least invigorating efforts.  Sult and Maines seem to be re-using some stuff at this point which isn't a great sign.  I swear I heard the riffs to \\"Child of the City\\" a half dozen times from this band.  This one is filler.  So is Rapture of Ridley Walker (a shame because the lyrics are great).  The same can be said for the re-recorded One Eye Dollar (appeared on the experimental Jam Room), which has no point other than Neil has said that live it flowed really well as a backside to Electric Worry.  It's a fun little song, but I think most of us Clutch fans would like to hear something NEW there. <br /> <br />All in all, it's a solid album.  If you're a Clutch fan you'll find plenty to love.  The first three songs rock as hard as anything they've done.  This band has a hard time doing anything wrong in my opinion.  When geniuses are a little lazy, you get From Beale Street to Oblivion.  They could have worked on this for another year, no doubt, and produced another five star album.  However, they are working class guys, and they need to make a living touring.  They're more popular than ever, and they needed to strike soon, when the iron was hot.  It all makes sense.  Still, there are some great moments here - the heavy metal urgency that kicks off the record, the continuation of full on baptism by blues courtesy of the First Holy Church of Clutch, Pastor Fallon ripping on vegans (haha!), and the same irresistible groove we've come to know and love. <br /> <br />Again, compared to Pure Rock Fury (the most aptly titled album ever, total punk-metal raw sludge blues), Blast Tyrant (every song is A+ - excellent editing, no filler), and Robot Hive/Exodus (their most creative release, lyrically and musically) this one falls a little short.

The cynicism of the dialogue leaves us pondering on, as Mr. Orlov says, the fact that a decent, honest job is done by too many people, with very thin margins, and yet, there are large fortunes to be made selling every kind of weapons he can get his amoral hands on.  <br /> <br />Since childhood, Mr. Orlov has been in love with a beautiful model and wherever he travels, as he sees the tabloids displaying her image, he focuses in someday possessing this \\"trophy wife\\" played by Bridget Moynahan. <br /> <br />At first, she is unaware of what he does for a living, and he convinces her that he is a millionaire in his own right, even though he has rented the plane he uses to take her away from a hotel where he had lured her under the disguise of photo opportunity. <br /> <br />Orlov's brother, played by Jared Leto, helps him to achieve his goals, but he is disturbed about the consequences of the trade they are in. As he sees countless victims die under the fire of the very weapons they sell, he finds refuge in his cocaine drug addiction, to mask the fact that he is an accomplice. <br /> <br />Yuri's cynicism is brilliantly played by Nicholas Cage, as he traffics in the death of thousands, the way other salesman might push vitamins or something good for humanity. <br /> <br />Some of the very cynical statements are left for the audience to ponder on the fact that \\"automobiles, alcohol and tobacco kill more people than weapons of all sorts.\\"  <br /> <br />Yuri Orlov travels all over the world, visiting a ruthless Liberian dictator, played by EamonnWalker, who acquires weapons to eliminate any citizen who opposes his oppressive regime. I understand my situation.\\" The reply is priceless... for the persecutor says... \\"I would send you to hell, but you already live there!\\" <br /> <br />While incredible dark humor is at play with this movie, I would highly recommend this film, for it surfaces the dangers of the arms race, and the high price we pay as nations continue to build arsenals of destruction. <br />

B00003CX9E|4.0|I am 62, and \\"Citizen Kane\\" has been hyped as the world's greatest film all of my life. I finally saw it for the first time when I was about 20, and even though I was in college earning a degree in journalism, and this is a movie partly about the journalism of the early 20th century, it really did not live up to the build-up. I viewed it again around the age of 40, and appreciated it a bit more. Finally, I watched it  again last week, and totally enjoyed it...the writing, acting, directing, odd style of story-telling, crazy camera angles, and all. When I was in college, a popular book was \\"Citizen Hearst\\", a biography of William Randolph Hearst, who Orson Welles was satirizing with his Kane character. Kane and Hearst share many traits in common, but the movie is not a thinly disguised biography of the Rupert Murdoch of his era. It is a work of fiction, a study of a man whose personality was shaped when he was a heart-broken boy, and whose inherited wealth led him to glory, power, even more wealth, and finally ruin. As is mentioned in the film, \\"Charles Foster Kane wanted to be loved\\" but he didn't know how to get it except through purchase or pandering. Don't worry if it does not knock your socks off the first time you see it. It is the kind of film that a person who has lived long enough to have a few big failures, and a success or two, will appreciate more.
B000ICL3KG|5.0|This film benefits from a presentation that has been refined and developed by it's presenter Al Gore for over 20 years.<br /><br />It's visual presentation by reknowned director Davis Guggenhiem is spotless.<br /><br />There is a sense of incisive modernism to the direction, and it casts what is essentially a powerpoint file accompanied by Gore's gently witty narrative into sharp focus.<br /><br />For me, the most powerful aspect of this project, aside from the crushing facts of global warming, is Gore's selfless dedication to his topic. He quotes Winston Churchill at one point, and appropriately, because like Churchill, Gore's moral universe is simplified by one unassailable fact - he has a mission, and he will not ever stop working at it.<br /><br />There is a tendency to criticise a film of this kind by creating doubt about a detail of it. For example, why is Gore seen in the film in a number of vehicles including helicopters, whilst preaching that we should all lower our carbon emissions? And the fairly overt shots of Apple laptops seem a little insidious when coupled with the knowledge that Gore is a director on the board of Apple computers.<br /><br />To criticise in this way though is really missing the forest for the trees. A man does not devote himself to an issue with this much passion for 4 decades just to draw attention to himself, and anyone looking into Gore's eyes can tell that he means what he says. Gore is far from an attention seeker; his presentation is a very sophisticated attempt to blast through the barriers of doubt. In fact this film shows how he spends an almost equal amount of time studying doubt and how to tackle it, as he does researching the science itself.<br /><br />My only quibble with the film is most probably a fault of the producer/directors in the mercifully few moments where we step outside Gore's presentation to study Gore himself and the shards of his life which intersect with the issue of Global Warming.<br /><br />Although these moments are in their own way, powerful and sympathetic, they also form a platform upon which the film can be superficially criticised (ie that he's just trying to draw attention to himself after losing an election, or that he's attempting to politicise science etc) and moronic as these criticisms may be, the film was better off not entering into the personal realm of Gore in my opinion. That could perhaps be another film. This film is and must be soley about the Earth, and the problem that confronts it.<br /><br />In short, this is a powerful, deeply human experience and one that leaves it's audience immediately inspired to do what we can for our beautiful home. I hope it is seen by as many people as possible and that they open their hearts and minds to it.etic, they also form a platform upon which the film can be superficially criticised (ie that he's just trying to draw attention to himself after losing an election, or that he's attempting to politicise science etc) and moronic as these criticisms may be, the film was better off not entering into the personal realm of Gore in my opinion. B00028HBKM|5.0|I cannot comment on the other languages, but the Latin pronunciation used is not the classical Latin pronunication probably in use at that time.  It is a later pronunciation widely used by the Roman Catholic Church and characteristic of versions of Latin that became the Romance languages.      Although this is a remarkable dramatic work, even believers may need to be reminded that it is still merely a movie, representing or dramatizing, but of course not recording, real events, including Jesus' resurrection, just as a movie about, say, Lincoln's assassination would depict, but cannot actually record, real events of 1865.  Dramatic representations of the Passion are so commonplace that one would easily feel encouraged to think of it as myth and to forget that it all actually happened, in just one way, as real events do happen.  No photographs survive, not because there was no scene to be photographed, but because photography came along some 1830 years later.  However obvious this may be, I fear that it needs to be said.
B000JLTRKE|5.0|This, along with United 93, was one of the two best movies I saw last year, and I am picky and do not get to see all that many. Nick Cage is good, but his co-star steals the show. As with the United 93 film, the protagonists do not know what caused the day's tragic events, what was happening elsewhere, or whether their precarious situations would have any wider meaning than just to themselves and their loved ones. Oliver Stone turns in a restrained, non-conspiracy, non-paranoid, non-obscene, and oddly, a nearly non-violent work of art here. A lot of it is filmed in the dark, with only the heads and maybe one hand visible on each actor, and with dialogue hampered by their injuries and desperate situation. Yet it is quite powerful, and to me, a total success.
B000NVIXFK|3.0|For me Rush was at their peak from \\"Power Windows\\" to \\"Roll the Bones\\", four albums of clean power rock with lots of hooks. The later CD's displayed fine musicianship, but the muse had fled, the songs simply weren't compelling.<br /><br />Sometime later after the band basically ceased to be for personal reasons, here's one more try at the brass ring.  The problem is that the band hasn't had a linear progression, they haven't grown as a group into new music, and this CD shows them essentially trying to recapture the past.  With some success, there are moments here that work, offset by the trademark Rush choppiness in song writing (someone said Rush sounds like they assemble songs from individual parts, so true).  Even when they sound good, like in parts of \\"Armor and Sword\\" and \\"Good News First\\", the only really solid songs here, it's so . . . old and familiar.  Is there really justification for adding another song to \\"Presto\\"?  Just because they can still manage it?  I don't know, maybe that's what the true believers want (or an even older sound maybe).<br /><br />If that was it, they basically pull off a repeat of one of the glory albums, that might be enough for me too.  But they don't, there are too many songs here that are hookless and drifting, and a lot of noodling around almost as filler.  The band sounds pretty good, just a little tired maybe, so there could be some hope that they stay together and find a new sound to push into, something to revitalize the songwriting.  But that's very rare, for a band to lose the ability to write hooks and then find it again.  I'm not very encouraged that Rush is going to find their second wind based on the evidence of this CD.
B00000IQCA|5.0|Why all the hate for FEADY TO WEAR?  Like many of you, I was underwhelmed when it first came out but now thanks to constant showings on the Sundance Channel and all those channels in that narrow band of indie cable, it has been growing on me and now I can't stop watching it.  Barbara Shulgasser's writing is wonderful, and if it has been chopped up like cole slaw by Altman's fitful direction, and by the generally improvisatory style embodied by Kim Basinger's steamrolling fashion reporter, it is still Altman who gives the picture its life, its joie de vivre.  And the fantastic outfits are to die for, each one crazier than the last.<br /><br />Sophia Loren is so over the top in this one role that retrospectively her entire career takes on a veneer of camp Carlo Ponti could never have intended.  If she was Elton John her sunglasses couldn't get any vaster, like two TV screens perched on her nose, and her breasts bobbing like apples in the tub of her sausage cased cleavage deserve equal billing with Mastroianni, who perhaps overdoes his sad sack clown persona.  Together they're not so much fun as you'd think, but she's great.  Is there any black satin left in the world or was all of it used for her widows' wear!<br /><br />My favorite, Anouk Aimee, gets all the drama parts.  Why didn't Altman use Anouk Aimee more, she is simply the most striking and hawklike actress who ever lived!  She and Rupert Everett as her avaricious son are playing out whole 3 decker Balzac novels with their back and forth, their mutual accusations of greed and contempt.<br /><br />OK, there are some inanities to READY TO WEAR, and I'm never sure if Forest Whitaker isn't laughing up his sleeve or revealing new previously unknown dimensions to his private life, but all in all it is a movie for the ages, and my favorite by Altman (except for NASHVILLE and A WEDDING).  Maybe its angle about fashion being stupid is itself pretty banal, but you know, I just don't care any more.  If it's on, I'll watch it all the way through and I'll cry when it's over, just like Julia Roberts pretending her lost luggage hasn't yet been delivered to her closet.watch it all the way through and I'll cry when it's over, just like Julia Roberts pretending her lost luggage hasn't yet been delivered to her closet.

Eastwood tries to tell too much, I think, and the flashbacks get annoying eventually. Two separate 90-minute movies, along with the third part of the trilogy, \\"Letters From Iwo Jima\\", giving the Japanese point of view, would have worked better. Still, this battle was ferocious and deserves to be honored for more than the 15-seconds of flag-raising on the fifth day of a 36-day fight. Read the book first, then see the DVD, if you are interested at all in the next-to-last great battle of the Pacific War.
