B000O178BY|5.0|Listen to this record a few times before you pass judgment. Even listening to it the first time, I thought...why would he do this?    The second time through, I paid more attention to the music and what he is trying to do.    The third time through, I got it.  Pay attention to what he is telling you through the music.  His message is not about the state of geo-political nonsense.      The message is about you.  All the songs together are about what's inside of you.  It is your own hand that is reaching from the heavens and shaping your life.    Whereas his past songs have been very angst filled and in your face, and moaning about his ex girls and drugs and abuse, here he is telling you a story and you need to pay attention.  He is doing it without screaming in your face and frankly with much less profanity than he is used to.  This may be by design so he gets his message out to a wider play audience.    I think this record is a perfect continuation from With Teeth because the last song on With Teeth is about looking at yourself and being afraid of what you might see in the mirror...now he is telling you what is actually there, whether you like it or not.    **UPDATE - Be sure to have your windows down, subs pumping hard in your car and you can feel the energy that you are creating.  Lots of magic worked with bass and I must say that the bass is very clean sounding. B000NVIXFK|4.0|I've been looking forward to this for quite a while and I haven't been disappointed.  Is it the greatest Rush album ever?  No, but it's a very solid effort from a group of musicians that continue to change and explore new areas every single album. <br /> <br />Overall, S&A is a lot slower paced that most Rush albums- they can still rock out if they want (the stellar single Far Cry) but much of the album feels more relaxed and introspective.  Tunes like The Larger Bowl, Faithless and Bravest Face take a look around the world and don't always like what they find.  The 3 instrumental tracks are some of the best on the album- consummate musicians simply playing what they feel like.  (Ergo the wonderfully titled Malignant Narcissism)  My only real criticism is that the album feels a bit disjointed- with the lead off Far Cry you expect a different album than what comes later, and it seems to shift tempo and tone too frequently. <br /> <br />The production on this album is *vastly* better than on Vapor Trails.  It sounds clean and precise throughout- you don't lose any of the subtle guitar tricks or drum backing in the wall of noise so common on their previous album <br /> <br />I think a lot of the negative reviews are by folks who keep hoping they'll return to the good old days.  (Which good old days is another story- 2112?  Moving Pictures?)  They are in their mid-50s now, but they are still amazingly technically proficient.  They've been playing music for decades, have done basically everything a rock band can do. have been through personal highs and tragedies, and I can't imagine they need the money anymore.  Why on earth would you think they'd produce an album like those in the past?   <br /> <br />Finally, I was amazed by the review that thought the lyrics, especially Faithless were too negative.  Not even close- Faithless is an anthem for us atheists/agnostics/humanists/skeptics.  It has without a doubt the most uplifting lyrics of any Rush tune in ages.
B000EMGAOY|3.0|This new album from the Chilis has some good moments and some not so good moments. I have listened to the whole thing twice and i like 16 of the 28 songs. The album seems to really run out of steam on the second disc when the vocal melodies of Kiedis and Frusciante's guitar riffs seem to blend into the next song and nothing really stands out. They start sounding like a lukewarm radio rock band and sound a bit cliched. The Chilis are a great band and i liked californication and By The Way but i think this album suffers from a lack of quality control. The whole point of doing double albums is normally to broaden out and experiment, and try things that the band has not done before. Most of the great double albums like the White Album by The Beatles, Mellon Collie and the infinite sadness by the Smashing Pumpkins or London Calling by The Clash do this, they take creative risks which manage to hold the listeners attention. Unfortunately on this album the Chilis only have a couple of experimental songs like If. Most of the album is a mix of Californian pop ballads, light rock and some funk and basically offers nothing that the Chilis haven't already done better on previous albums. Having said that the album is good, the first 8 songs on the first disc are all good, but the album gets a bit patchy after that point. One of the major problems is Kiedis's vocals are a bit uninspired and the lyrics are random with nothing very interesting or evocative to say, so a lot of these songs sound a bit samey after a while. However, there are good songs on here and the album is worth buying if you're a Chilis fan and if the 16 best songs were on one disc this would be a 4 star album.

B000002ILG|2.0|The guitar solo in White Lion's \\"Wait\\" is a LIMP-WRISTED DINOSAUR. It's a blast of subconscious femininity spewed to the surface by its steel-eyed, steel-toed creator, Italian Long Islander Vito Bratta. Its sweep-picked dips and launches are as fluid as milk on moisturized spine tissue, its bendy hammer-ons as eerily scraped clean of excess noise as a Svenson silencer. It makes the man who was undoubtedly Bratta's greatest influence, Eddie Van Halen, sound like the sloppiest spank maven of all time. Even the opening finger-tapping on \\"Hot For Teacher\\" has traces of misplaced pick-induced grit and grime. This solo is more sterilized than a Norwegian maternal ward. It's a major-key lite-toned crystal clear hang-gliding ascent towards hair metal heaven, where all the glammy apostles freely accept the most feminine aspects of their genre, without resorting to horrifically homophobic cover-up a la Sebastian Bach of Skid Row (not even Axl Rose had the gall to don an \\"AIDS Kills F**s Dead\\" shirt on live TV). Bratta's solo inadverdently begs all metaldom to embrace the tender and shun the hedonistic. <br /> <br />And why not? After all, the song is one of the most disgustingly sincere metal ballads of all time, with lyrics like \\"Wait, wait, I never had a chance to love you.\\" Released in 1988, the same year an onslaught of more well-received (yet no more substantive) glam ballads such as \\"Every Rose Has Its Thorn\\" and \\"Don't Know What You Got 'Till It's Gone\\" hit international airwaves, \\"Wait\\" bears a positivity, an angelic wholesomeness, that places it in a slightly different league than its ilk. This song isn't lamenting an affair or love gone bad; its narrator is merely asking his love interest to be a little more patient, and you know from all the triumphant chanting that she'll concede. <br /> <br />White Lion played \\"gee whiz\\" metal. They were guilty of all the same glam posturing as their peers; guitarists playing back-to-back, scarf on the mic stand, three members sharing a mic, a singer more splashy than Joan Jett and Uma Thurman's potential love child. What set them apart from the others was their purity, their love of monogamy and harmony. After all, their second single was an ode to those heart-wrenching moments \\"When The Children Cry.\\" Sex and booze are noticeably missing from their videos. And Bratta's solo, all white-furred lynx preening and cream acrobatics, is a paean all its own, the patron saint of altruistic heavy metal.
B000NVIXFK|4.0|I love reading the varied reviews on this latest RUSH disc.  Either you love it or you just hate it.  Basically, it's coming down to two sides of the camp.  The pre-Hemispheres fans, the pre-Grace Under Pressure fans and then thereafter.  The die hard fans would have 2112, Caress of Steel, or Hemispheres, etc for every single album.  That just doesn't work and bands don't last with the same exact sound for each outing.  With each release I would hope that each fan would want a different type of album.  While I can appreciate the more progressive feel of early RUSH I can also appreciate the latest sound of RUSH.  Although this does border on the sound of Vapor Trails I won't decry it until I've listened to it for awhile.  Vapor Trails and even Test For Echo took me a long time to thoroughly enjoy after much listening.  But then again, Permanent Waves and Hemispheres took me a long time to actually enjoy.  And while some reviewers ridicule this cd then you might be the one's who also were shocked when Permanent Waves came out with the radio friendly 'The Spirit of Radio'.  If that wasn't a sell-out by RUSH to commercial radio then I don't know what was.  I remember when I first heard it I just hated that song because after listening to RUSH, Caress of Steel, Fly By Night, 2112 back in the day and 'All the World's a Stage' I just wanted more of the same.  But,unfortunately, that's not the case with musicians who want to grow in their respected fields.  So, although this might not be their best cd to date according to you, at least the band is still making music.  The bottom line is that the band is happy with this release.  Just like with Genesis and their very commercial releases with Phil Collins it was a band decision with each album that was made.  Whether or not the fans were happy has always been a matter of much debate.  Take a listen and be open to the sound of a great rock album, not a progressive masterpiece of yesteryear. Stand-out track so far for me would be 'The Larger Bowl'.  The addition of the acoustic guitar in the majority of songs gives this cd a different touch even if it's in unison with the electric guitar and even with the overdubbing of Geddy Lee on backing vocals it doesn't detract from the cd.  If you see them in concert Alex then takes the reign of back-up vocalist and you have to wonder if he actually does the back-up vocal duties on their cd's.  Who knows and what's done in the studio to what is actually played on tour are different anyway for the most part and you expect that.  So, don't trash this on expectations of 20-30 years ago.  If you do, you will be sorely disappointed. For all the negative reviews, they just aren't warranted.  After many listens I would to lean more towards this being a exceptional release that is much better than Test For Echo and Vapor Trails all the way around.be 'The Larger Bowl'. After many listens I would to lean more towards this being a exceptional release that is much better than Test For Echo and Vapor Trails all the way around.

B000NVIXFK|3.0|I was experiencing a logical disconnect with my original disappointment in this album (see original review below).  Snakes & Arrows is Rush, and therefore should be completely awesome.  However, I found the album somewhat wanting.      Then I figured it out.      When I saw the songs performed live (MSG on September 17, 2007), they TOTALLY ROCKED.  I came away with a completely new appreciation for the album.  All I found lacking in the musical aspect of the album was totally blown away by that one concert.  I even liked \\"Spindrift\\", which I had found particularly grating. It may just be that a mere CD cannot contain the awesomeness that is Rush.  And that could be why Rush felt this was their best album to date (which had some fans scratching their heads)--they were hearing it LIVE as they recorded it.  Had I first heard the music live, I might have felt the same way.      Do I still have some issues with the album?  Sure.  I think Neil's lyrics are particularly depressing and fatalistic this time around (can \\"The Way the Wind Blows\\" really have been written by the same man who gave us \\"Everyday Glory\\"?!), and if the songs are only one-hundredth as good on the CD as they are live, that's an engineering or production problem, I think.      So if you are a fan who found this album somewhat disappointing, I can completely sympathize--and encourage you to get tickets next time they come around.  It'll completely change your outlook.  I promise. :)    -----  Original Review:  As eagerly as I anticipated this album, I am rather disappointed by my first run-through.  None of the tracks really grabbed me.  Snakes and Arrows features some musical snippets that really could have BEEN something under the right direction (I kept waiting for those melodies to swell and transform into something incredible, I could hear it there under the surface!), but in the end was not particularly remarkable.      I think lack of energy is really the big fault of this album.  As I listened tothe somewhat plodding tempos and similar-sounding songs, the only thing running through my mind was the opening bars of \\"Force 10\\".  THAT has power and force and passion and makes you want to DO something, express yourself, revel in the joy that they create with their music.  And for heaven's sake, when you see them live...whoo!      However, the album is still Rush and therefore worth your time.  Neil's lyrics (and use of a pantoum) are very HIM, as usual (can't put it any other way!), and although Geddy seems to have acquired a somewhat excessive fascination with layering his own voice over the past few albums, his bass playing is second to none and he sings well.  Alex, perhaps inspired by his success with the opening theme to \\"Andromeda\\", provides us with a fun, quirky little instrumental all his own that is less like \\"Victor\\" than one might have feared.      Even if Snakes and Arrows is not one of Rush's best, I will of course give the album many many more listens.  A ruby among diamonds is still precious, no?
B000NVIXFK|5.0|I have to comment on this album. Being a long time Rush fan, and after listening to Vapor Trails (not my favorite album by a stretch) I thought Rush may had actually run out of good new material. But boy was I wrong, this album is so fresh and yet flavored with classic Rush sound, that it blew me away! They have risen up to make a fantastic piece of work here that I know die hard Rush fans will enjoy more than Vapor Trails by a looooooooooooooooong shot! What I have noticed with almost every Rush album is that, there seems to be at least a few \\"filler\\" type songs (I hate to say it) on every one of them, songs that are so weak, I can't even listen to them even once in their entirety. But I'm going to say that every song on this album is very, very good if not amazing in it's sound and construction. Alex has really stepped up his game and added some guitar sounds like he has never done before. Geddy is really tight on the bass and has also ventured into some \\"rif\\" oriented sounds unlike any I have heard before. Neil is simply Neil, and shines as he always does. Together, they have produced an album that to this long time Rush listener, has to rank amongst their very, very best of all time!
B000NVIXFK|4.0|Today I read a review of Snakes & Arrows on the CANOE.ca website and I think the author put it best in describing Rush as a band that always acts its age.  So it shouldn't surprise anyone that the lyrics and sounds with each subsequent album have evolved and reflect the life experiences, interests and concerns of the band.  That this new album isn't 2112 is no surprise to me and it is really perplexing that others expected it to be or even wanted it to be as such.  These guys are not 20 years old anymore.  They may still be interested in sci-fi and themes seen in their younger work, but they have grown up, evolved into more complex adults who I'm guessing have many other concerns and have been influenced by life, politics, art and other music.  I can totally relate to that.  I like this album.  It takes the feel and chord progressions from older Rush albums but projects them into the future--there's that evolution theme--to show us the more advanced stages of these three excellent musicians.  I especially like The Way the Wind Blows and Faithless.  The lyrics are also very thoughtful and intricate, as always.  The musicianship is also brilliant, still evolving and improving which we expect from these guys.  It seems the people who criticize this album because it doesn't sound like the older albums from this or that Rush era have forgotten that you can never go back.  All they would need to do is look at their own lives to realize this is true.  So why would you require this of Rush?
B000HC2LI0|5.0|First off, while one can't judge a series, either on broadcast of DVD, by its packaging, Warner Home Video pulled out all the stops for the complete series edition.  A dispatch box is a great way of presenting one of the seminal political TV shows ever, and putting the early seasons on single-side DVD, although a small thing, was a wise choice. <br /> <br />But packaging isn't what makes me buy a series collection.  It's the series itself, and here's where \\"The West Wing\\" was strongest - writing.  Aaron Sorkin is the KING of brilliant plotting and dialogue, and this series puts it all on display.  The first three seasons - where Sorkin was most involved - were strong on character, plot, and snappy, witty dialogue, even when the overall story faltered or the plotlines were too gimmicky.  Nobody has this much on their plate when they don't seek out conflict - an assasination, war scares, assorted horrors - and if they do, there's bound to be a flummox along the way. <br /> <br />The strange thing is that \\"The West Wing,\\" like Sorkin's \\"The American President,\\" is smart but a little too idealistic with the main characters.  Sure, President Jed Bartlet is a caring, cautious, even, dare I say it, dignified, president, but he's been around the maypole long enough to know that deals have to be done.  Martin Sheen delivers a nuanced performance - easy I guess because the politics of his character mimic his real-life ones.  The pragmatic voice-on-his-shoulder, Leo McGarry, done by the ever brilliant John Spencer (we had him for only a short time on the \\"must have\\" list for character actors before he died), was the only voice of pragmatism in Bartlet's White House. <br /> <br />I agree with other assessments that the series really suffered when Sorkin left.  His creative hand made the \\"Wing\\" the hit it was early on, and they struggled mightily after he left.  However, the show was bigger than it's creator, much as it was bigger than its ensemble cast (Moira Kelley and Rob Lowe must kick themselves every day when they think of how willingly they bailed on a hit show).  The series struggled to recapture its lustre in the later seasons, but they did hit stride again when, in a burst of daring reality, decided to end the show after Bartlet's two terms were up.  We've seen before how producers and networks, unwilling to let a hit go, despite knowing the best years are behind them, thus force a good show to die a death of mediocrity.  However, John Wells and Tommy Schlamme (the second creative genius on this project) brought their best work into showing a realistic election campaign while allowing us to see a bittersweet ending of a career that would be equally missed in the real world, including the disintegration of a personal/professional relationship over a leak scandal, and the challenge of doing the right thing for the person when it comes to handing out a pardon (surely one of the hardest things a real president must do).  Thus, even without Sorkin, we see a good series save its best truly for last. <br /> <br />Wrapped up in all this, as expected, are some great behind-the-scenes goodness and additional materials exclusive for this edition (a reprint of the \\"Pilot\\" shooting script and essential episode guide) which add to both the series and the real world behind it.  Truly, this is well worth the price, which while considerable is much better in this set than buying all the boxes seperately.

B000NVIXFK|5.0|The music on Snakes & Arrows is powerful.  From the galloping intensity of \\"Far Cry\\" to the subtlty of \\"Hope\\" (solo acoustic guitar) to the passion of \\"Faithless\\" to the incredible musicianship on \\"Main Monkey Business\\", it's all here.  Rush is not a Pop band.  They write intense, often dramatic music to go along with the lofty, philosophical topics that they sing about.  But that does not mean they don't know how to lay down beautiful, uplifting melodies and dynamics.  This album really conveys conviction, hope, desperation, anger and joy while singing about some of the big problems the world faces because of a militant, fanatical style of religious adherence.  Timely songs for a troubled time.  Rush is ALL HEART!!  Get this CD, make sure you can listen to it loud and prepare yourself to be taken away with melody, incredible drumming, incredible guitar work, lush arrangments and soaring vocals!   After many listens I have concluded that this is absolutely one of Rush's best albums.  You just have to give it a chance to sink in.  Just AMAZING!!

B000NVIXFK|4.0|I'm a longtime Rush fan.  I always try to appreciate each new release as an essential chapter in the band chronicles, even if some don't find favor with my peculiar listening tastes.  I like all of their albums on some level, but I also find that some don't move me like 2112, Permanent Waves, Grace Under Pressure and Counterparts.  Roll the Bones is my least favorite; to my ears it lacks bottom end and weight both from the audio standpoint and the song formulae.  Hold Your Fire alternates between songwriting brilliance and far too many synths.  Test For Echo lacks memorable or crafty melodies and Vapor Trails sounds terrible.  Again, I love Rush and will always support them.  But for me some releases don't warrant alot of revisiting. <br /> <br />Snakes and Arrows, though I've only had time to listen once since I bought it, strikes me as a very strong effort.  I've been listening to Far Cry now since it was first available on iTunes and I have enjoyed it immensely:  Heavy guitars, a bizarre stomping intro riff and one of their most memorable chorus melodies of the last 20 years.  A great mix of classic guitar-driven Rush and their best songwriting efforts of the 90's, Far Cry serves to me as a represntative slice of Snakes and Arrows' appeal. <br /> <br />Much has been made of Alex's acoustic flavors on this album, and I would agree that they are in prominence and one of several reasons this disc stands on its own as a singular statement by the band.  For me, however, the strength of this release is the bold thematic statement running throughout Neil's lyrics.  Nearly every song ponders the question of faith and existence, and the strange and absurd juxtapositions of the modern cult of the supernatural and the harshness of life in the 21st (and to a metaphorical extent, the 7th) Century.  Taking cues from the intensely personal themes of crushing loss on Vapor Trails, Neil wears a heavy, sad and angry heart on his sleeve, skewering the idea of \\"faith\\" and the hypocrisy of religion as superstition.  Regardless of whether the listener agrees or not, the lyrics are bold and often pointed and adresses a social phenomenon with the poigniancy and strength of Presto's \\"The Pass\\" and the jarring clarity of Counterparts' \\"Nobody's Hero.\\" <br /> <br />The instrumentals are, as usual, excellent.  For my money, Main Monkey Business and Malignant Narcissism are better than any instrumental since Moving Pictures' YYZ.  They have a melodic strength and depth or hormony, with enough rhythmic happiness going on to please the Peart-worshippers and enough guitars to herald the triumphant return of Alex Lifeson, the tonal texture man.   <br /> <br />And, speaking of Alex, rumors that he is still holding out on guitar solos are unfounded and inaccurate.  True he is not soloing on every song but rather plays a solo in the service of the song.  There are several searing solos on this CD and a couple of them are the most fiery since his masterwork of pop guitar solos in Signals' \\"The Analog Kid.\\"  Not only has Alex found his inner folkie (his guitar instrumental \\"Hope\\" is wonderful), he has found peace with his recent, more solo-eschewing persona.  He has stripped his approach to a visceral basic with hints of blues and 60's riffage (with a nod to Feedback) and with that emphasis-shift reminded us why he is consistently rated near the top of the classic rock guitarists. <br /> <br />If you like Rush, you probably have no issues with Geddy's voice.  While I still have some issues with the vocal layering and harmonies that can detract from the overall product, my initial perception on Snakes and Arrows is that Geddy is making wiser choices about where and how to use the vocal harmonies; more often than not he is using his voice where synth pads used to reside in the mix, and when harmonizing with a melody the arrangements seem a bit more thoughtful and alot less intrusive.  Add to that a deepening richness and maturity in Geddy's vocal quality (check out the excellent \\"The Larger Bowl\\") and we have a vast improvement over Vapor Trails and Test For Echo. <br /> <br />In all, Snakes and Arrows, to me, stands as an excellent release and is the best Rush album since Counterparts.  Bold and bright sounding (easily the best SOUNDING Rush record in recent years), it will merit many repeat listening sessions.  Check it out.
B00000JSJC|1.0|since I cannot give this film a 'no' star, which clearly is what it deserves, it will garner a '1' star for the magical talent of Ray Fiennes. Despite that the film is non-stop boredom, fast paced 'huh's?' and a tendancy to leave the room multiple times, without being angry or irritated that you missed even a second of it. B000NVIXFK|4.0|I'm really not sure where all of the negativity is coming from on Snakes and Arrows.  It's just a completely different sound and approach and perhaps this is just it.  It's what people aren't used to that they dislike I guess. I dunno.  If you look back on Rush's career, they've changed their sound and whole outlook about every four albums or so.  You've got the Rush through 2112 era, Kings through Pictures, Signals through Fire, you get the idea.  In recent years, Rush has gone on hiatus, devoting more time to develop personal interests of which, these experiences I think, have only added depth to their songs.  IMHO Snakes and Arrows shows just that.   <br /> <br />If you give the album (ok CD or... MP3s, so I'm dating myself) a chance, I think you can find some pretty good material in here. B000O178BY|5.0|It's not until the fifth track, \\"Vessel,\\" that one begins to appreciate just how sublimely crazy and dense Reznor's album is. I might not be able to understand the lyrics clearly through all the acidic, shifting buzz, but the cadence and snarling howl is classic NIN -- while the soundscape around him is magnetic, unsettling, enigmatic and sleek. He's been reading the newspapers, he doesn't like what he sees, and he is now going to give it to you with both barrels. And rock your face.<br /><br />I don't think I've ever used such descriptions when talking about an album, but it's just such a nimble and assured sonic experience that I am constantly amazed from one passage to the next. He's transcended his own sound and broken through to something chillingly propulsive. And I am fascinated at how he has finally, finally pulled free of the debilitatingly meticulous delivery that blunted his fire on admittedly strong releases like The Fragile and With Teeth. Year Zero is gloriously loose and inventive. From track to track, you can see he's knee-deep in a goldmine of inspiration, raining heavy nuggets down on the listener.<br /><br />Some artists find a great sound and drive it into the ground in successive albums. Others have a mid- or late-career snap of feverish inspiration, a purge of thought that finds a powerful musical channel that leads directly to the hindbrain. This is that place. If you don't get it, you're not listening loudly enough.

B000NVIXFK|3.0|I've enjoyed Rush for years, but I'm definitely a fan of their early stuff. B000NVIXFK|5.0|It's tough to tell how to read the reviews for the new CD. Out of the whole album, Far Cry and The Larger Bowl are what captivated me most, although Malignant Narcissism was testorone cool. That said it does not crack my top five (Moving Pictures, Permanent Waves, 2112, Counterparts, and Vapor Trails). There is an urgency that is missing in the album after Far Cry. This album reminds me more of 1989's Presto, very thoughtful, reflective but lacking the energy. I loved Peart lyrics on that album, but not the musical interpretation. Same with this one. That said, for any Rush head, this is a must and a chance to hear Alex play accoustic and get into Neil's head a little bit.

B000NVIXFK|5.0|Let's be honest here.  The enjoyment of music is a highly personal and subjective experience. The only way you can know is to give it a listen.  So, I suggest that you ignore anyone that evangelizes their opinion as through it were fact and instead trust your own judgment.  <br /> <br />That being said, my own personal reaction is that this album is excellent. B000000OUJ|5.0|This is really a great disc. The GZA isn't my favorite Wu-Tang MC and (people will hate my for this) I don't think he's the most talented (I'm gonna side with Ghost) and I certainly don't think this is the best We solo disc (Cuban Linx has a tighter concept.) But, again, this is a really great disc. <br />  It showcases what the GZA does best, and that's old school rhymes with clever metaphors and punchlines. RZA's production on Liquid Swords is slowed down from Cuban Linx and even 36 Chambers, which allows the GZA to move at his own pace. The most prominent guests - Method Man and Inspectah Deck - work well to complement what is going on. Indeed, I don't think Deck has sounded better than this album (Duel of the Iron Mic, Cold World.) Meth's work on Shadowboxin' makes some of the dopest verses you'll ever hear (\\"fiend to catch a n***a snoozin'/slip the cardiac/arrest me/exorcist hip-hop possess me/crunch a n***a like a Nestle/you know my steeze\\") <br />  The Genius also has a chance to shine on concept songs like Labels and Killah Hills 10304 in a way that he doesn't on Wu-Tang posse tracks. As mentioned by other reviewers, Labels is constructed around the names record labels and is a cautionary tale about thinking that a record deal is going to solve your problems (\\"Tommy ain't my muthaf***in Boy/when he fakes moves on a n***a he employ\\".) Killah Hills is the kind of in-depth drug dealer narrative that you would expect from Ghostface or Raewkwon, but the GZA holds his own, creating an even grimier scene than either of them (except maybe Ghost's \\"Malcom\\" from Supreme Clientele.) <br />  The only \\"problems\\" occur when GZA flows over quicker beats with quicker MCs - notably on 4th Chamber and Investigative Reports. RZA, Rae and Ghost have such quick, dexterous flows and rapid fire rhymes that the songs seem to drag under the GZA's straight-forward, laid-back delivery. I realize this has more to do with preferences, so I still give the album five stars, but it's something that's always stood out to me. <br />  All in all, this is a fantastic piece of work from a very talented MC and worth every penny you would ever have to pay for it. It makes me long for the golden era of mid-90's NY hip-hop. Buy, listen, enjoy.
B000O75F7C|5.0|Porcupine Tree has been one of my favorite bands for years; picking up the gauntlet thrown down by '70s progressive rock groups such as Pink Floyd, King Crimson and Rush...they have gained much acclaim over the last few years due to some excellent reviews and publicity surrounding their last few albums- I suppose it's only fitting that 2007 brings us yet another masterpiece from Steven Wilson and Co., and that it features guest appearances from both Robert Fripp and Alex Lifeson, prog greats and obvious influences themselves.<br /><br />Fans have been torn somewhat as of late by the seeming split between the early, spacey-trance-psychedelia evident on older PT releases such as \\"Signify\\" and \\"Sky Moves Sideways\\" and the heavier, more rock-oriented approach on subsequent albums...most notably \\"In Absentia\\" and \\"Deadwing\\". Very much a continutation of the overall flow of \\"Deadwing\\", but with a few more moments of melancholy psychedelia. Very highly recommended, and one of the best prog rock bands out today.

They had shown signs of diversity on previous records and it comes to maturity here. The benefits of a band that can take advantage of their hard-won success and truly allow themselves to spread their wings (the Stones with Exile) are evident in songs like Ten Years Gone, In the Light, and Kashmir. The Rover, my favorite Zep song of all time is just one of the many memorable numbers here. If I had to pick one Led Zeppelin album to have, this is it, no questions asked.<br />All of Zeppelin's unpaid blues dues aside (and there are quite a few), Physical Graffiti, with songs full of awesome power, moving beauty, and influences from around the globe that redefined rock and roll, is the only evidence anyone needs to prove Led Zeppelin's rightful place in the top five rock acts of all time.

B000NVIXFK|5.0|Rush continues along their path of excellence with their latest effort, Snakes and Arrows. Although a first listen may not uncover all the masterful complexity this album has to offer, its one that offers new pleasures with each listening with songs that seem to get stronger with each play. A few things do immediately characterize this album - the always strong musicianship, unmistakeably Rush, for one. The songs all have an organic quality to them, having been composed primarily on acoustic guitar. Finally the superb production on this album allows all the nuances of each instrument to be heard properly, in perfect balance with the rest of the instruments.    Rush comes out swinging with Far Cry, notably punctuated with a complex time riff followed by a chord known to Rush fans as \\"The Hemispheres Chord\\". As evidenced by the number of teenage guitarists covering this song on YouTube, Alex is again playing stuff guitarists will want to cover.    Armor and Sword follows, combining acoustic flourishes with a heavy guitar riff reminiscent of Cygnus X-1 from A Farewell to Kings.     Working Them Angels has an evocative verse section and powerful and catchy chorus. Another very strong song continuing a strong start for this album. All three of these first songs are likely to be played in concert.    The Larger Bowl slows things down a bit with the most acoustically flavored tune so far along with some fairly sobering lyrics concerning the inherent unfairness in life.    Spindrift is one of those classic \\"dark\\" Rush songs, in the tradition of Witch Hunt, Between the Wheels, or Time and Motion. The lyrics are some of the most interesting I've seen from Peart alternating between overwhelming feelings from observing environmental elements(ie \\"As the waves crash in on the western shore\\") to more interpersonal lyrics directed at someone.(\\"where is the wave that will carry me a little closer to you\\")    The Main Monkey Business is undoubtedly \\"the masterpiece of the album\\" Neilalluded to months back in an interview. Its everything you could want from a Rush instrumental - its powerful, technical, and moving. Its as good or better than any instrumental they've ever done. (edit - I'm wrong - as Neil pointed out in a later interview, his masterpiece was Armor and Sword. From a lyrical standpoint, I'd agree, but where the music is concerned, I still say this song is the high point. ;) )    Next up is The Way the Wind Blows, with an uncharacteristic(for Rush), yet very powerful blues riff opening the song. Then, a hard rock riff and Geddy's voice takes over. Finally, an acoustic chorus, then back to the blues riff. A very interesting musical arrangement plus lyrics that continue the albums theme of religious extremism and its effects.    Hope is an acoustic instrumental by Alex, showcasing six and twelve string guitars as well as mandolin, mandola, and bouzouki. It's somewhat of a musical tour-de-force, with Celtic and Americana-tinged stylings, both relaxing and interesting to listen to.    Faithless continues the albums lyrical theme, this time covering exactly what the lyricist does and does not believe. While this song might be hard for someone religious to listen to, its basically a statement of the universe as the writer perceives it, (\\"I don't have faith in faith. I don't believe in belief\\") decrying blind faith while at the same time embracing love and hope.    Bravest Face contrasts the world portrayed in that classic Louis Armstrong tune, \\"Its a Wonderful World\\" or those TV shows where the ending is always happy with the world so many people have to live in each day. Yet the overall vibe is positive, with the lyrics exhorting the listener to face up to reality and \\"Put on your bravest face\\". It's another interesting musical arrangement, alternating between bluesy sounding acoustic and electric guitars and a powerful, melodic rock section.    Good News First is another cool song building from a somewhat quiet and spooky sounding verse section. The artwork for this song in the CD liner is especially striking...a crow pecks at a grave, while a wind-blown newspapers heading reads \\"Cure Discovered\\". Yes, the good news first, please. Incredibly deep lyrics on this one, this song could mean so many different things to different people.    Malignant Narcissism is the third instrumental on this album, its short and to the point. It's a little reminiscient of YYZ, but more modern sounding and with a few new surprises. Listen carefully to the drums on this one, Neil's playing a five-piece.    Finally, the album ends on an energetic high note with \\"We Hold On\\".     All in all, Snakes and Arrows has the goods. Not a single tune that I'd want to skip on a repeated listen. Its both interesting and new, yet reminiscent of classic Rush at the same time. Finally, Snakes and Arrows has the production a Rush album deserves; great songs deserve to sound great. Enjoy it, and if you don't get it at first, realize this is complex music and that it might take a few listens to really get whats going on.

038533348X|5.0|\\"Call me Jonah,\\" CAT'S CRADLE begins, referencing the unfortunate soul who got stuck in a whale.  This Jonah is a journalist who has decided to write a book about the architect of the bomb that \\"resolved\\" World War II.  It is not a spoiler to say that he learns after tracking the deceased scientist's post-war life and work that on the day the bomb was dropped, Dr. Newton Hoenikker was playing with a piece of string and as one of his now adult children observes of the children's game of the book's title, there was no cat, there was no cradle.  Much of the book becomes a chase down to a Caribbean island republic with a colorful bunch of characters, some accidentally and others not quite so accidentally caught up with the scientist's next big thing after the bomb.   <br /> <br />Vonnegut uses this absurd comic tale to comment seriously about the problem of unchecked power, whether it is scientific or political.  He gets in some views on religion, too, and invents an entire new one out of whole cloth, \\"Bokononism,\\" which is rife with its founder's sayings.  Rereading this 1963 book again in 2007 after thirty odd years, I am astounded at the number of prophetic passages that suggest things that later became a part of our cultural language, including  napalm, nuclear winter, Jonestown, Katrina, and politicians who don't \\"get it\\" about how America is regarded by the outside world.   <br /> <br />There is a warm, sad smile in Vonnegut's voice that makes his stuff compelling.  His is an inventive vision that melds the comic and fantastic with a shrewd, philosophical look below the surface of human dealings.  I especially like the passage in which he puts in his two cents on the value of writers, that they compare to firefighters and emergency personnel, and even college professors, because they all perform essential services to humanity. <br />
0312995423|3.0|DIGITAL FORTRESS is Dan Brown's debut, and is also his weakest novel.  I found it mildly enjoyable, because Brown is a very tight plotter and the pace of this book is very fast.  This novel is filled with a lot of action, and I kept turning the pages to see how everything would end.<br /><br />Unfortunately, DIGITAL FORTRESS has some major shortcomings.  Most of the characters (including the two main characters) are rather flat and uninteresting.  Many of the supporting characters are woefully underdeveloped.  The plot centers around computer technology, and I personally found Brown's explanations of this technology to be rather dry and boring.  I am admittedly not a techie, but there are sections of this book that read like a computer manual, and I found myself skipping certain paragraphs.<br /><br />The best part of DIGITAL FORTRESS involves the breaking of certain codes, which I found very enjoyable.  The best part of this novel is the ending, which is exciting and fun.  I wish the entire book was as thrilling as the last seventy-five or so pages.<br /><br />This novel is okay, but I personally believe that Brown's Robert Langdon novels are far superior.  I would definitely try those books, especially ANGELS & DEMONS, which I think is a genuinely great thriller.
0385335989|3.0|.  In this fourth volume of her time travel/romance series, Gabaldon continues the adventures of Claire and Jamie Fraser.  Shipwrecked on the coast of the American colonies, Claire and Jamie are making their way to North Carolina where many Scottish exiles have settled after serving time as indentured servants.  They are faced with the task of making a life in the wild, untamed American wilderness menaced by hostile Indians, bear, venomous snakes and disease.  But Claire and Jamie rise to the challenge.  Jamie accepts the offer of the Carolina governor to start a settlement on a beautiful mountain that will soon be known as \\"Fraser's Ridge\\" which he hopes to fill with former fellow Scottish prisoners from Ardsmuir.  But their lives are disrupted by the sudden appearance of their beloved daughter Brianna whom they believed to be safely settled in the future.  Brianna has risked her life to find Jamie and Claire to warn them that they are destined to die in a terrible fire in less than eight years. Although filled with joy to have Brianna join them, the Frasers are terrified by the dangers that colonial America provides to a young woman.  Following from the future is her lover and Claire's friend, Roger Wakefield, a Scottish historian who has fallen in love with Brianna.  Roger is the only man able to use the mysterious stones to travel to the past because he is the descendant of the witch Geilie, Claire's nemesis.  As usual, Gabaldon has crafted a lusty, exciting tale that propels the reader at a lightning pace through bear attacks, hangings, mystical encounters with ghosts and lots and lots of juicy sex.  At its heart, this is after all, a romance series, so the fiery passionate scenes between Claire and Jamie are still just as urgent and descriptive as Gabaldon's other volumes in the series.  It's refreshing to have a pair of middle-aged protagonists who still find delight in each other. However, I do concede that by this volume, Gabaldon's plot formulas sometimeswear thin. Her reluctance to end the series that is already many thousands of pages, means that Gabaldon often repeats plot devices like the resurrection of a supposedly dead character or the amazing coincidences that sometimes drive the story.  Still, the book is entertaining.

0307346609|2.0|First let it be known that I am a HUGE fan of zombie fiction. I even run a zombie book club in the city where I live. That said, this book was a tremendous let down for me. The author presents an incoherent picture of the world during and after a world wide zombie outbreak.  <br /> <br />Individual sections of the book truly shine and are well worth reading. But the author should have spent some time reading other alterate history war novels. Chief among my complaints is the lack of any kind of timeline or overview of the events. The experiences of the survivors are presented with no real context.  <br /> <br />Many intriguing things are mentioned in passing and then ignored. Examples that come to mind include an Israeli civil war and attempts at secession by people in the zombie occupied USA. Perhaps we as readers might be interested in just few details about the world where he has set the book. <br /> <br />Worse than that which is ignored, are certain inane assertions that the  author makes. The one that really set us off in our book club was when a character states that an overwhelming percentage of americans had no  war relevant skills because they are involved in some kind of information oriented white collar work and need to be retrained. This may seem true to the author, who is from a wealthy family (son of Mel Brooks), but is highly insulting to those of us who live in the real world where most people are blue collar workers who can repair their own homes. The author's grasp of how weapons work is also suspect. He informs us that artillery is of little use against zombies, because hydrostatic shock doesn't effect them. As a big nerd I have ask, how an expanding ball of white hot shrapnel fails to destroy brains. Plague of the Dead presents a much better account of how a millitary could fail against hordes of zombies simply by being overwhelmed. One further problem, is that he states that the outbreak is world wide, but portrays the US army retreating west as though the outbreak is primarily originating from the east coast. This is typical of the lack of thought put into this book. <br /> <br />His attempt to insert a little thinly veiled poltical commentary is hamhanded and awkward. Certain politicians are implied to be real people from our world, but the author lacks the courage to refer to them by name and write a real alternate history. As result, the inclusion of these people feels forced and detracts from story. <br /> <br />In short, I give this book two stars because it comes so close to being a great zombie novel, and then repeatedly dissapoints. If you really like zombies, spend your money on Plague of the Dead, Day by Day Armageddon, or one of the many better zombie novels written in recent years.

B000NVIXFK|5.0|Alex Lifeson commented during a radio interview several months ago how Snakes & Arrows was one of the quickest recordings since 1977's Farewell to Kings album, and the spontaneous takes and instant energies are beautifully detected on what marks another chapter in the Rush history. When you hear the fierce rockin' introduction followed by the griding guitar hooks on the lead song \\"Far Cry,\\" you immediately know that Rush are back. Like before, their words feel as if time is slowing down and make you ponder as Geddy Lee sings, \\"One day I feel like I'm on top of the world and the next it's falling in on me, but I can get back on.\\" Rush has reclaimed a light from their glory days throughout much of the album. As always, their songs continue to pose questions and draw conclusions with Neil Peart's common sense outlook mixed with philosophy. \\"Way the Wind Blows\\" reflects on appreciating the here and now as Lee sings, \\"We can only bow to the here and now or be broken blow by blow,\\" and \\"Faithless\\" is actually about having faith. \\"I don't have faith in faith, I don't believe in belief, you can call me faithless, you can call me faithless. I still cling to hope and I believe in love and that's faith enough for me,\\" make up the chorus. A great follow-up to 2002's Vapor Trails plus has the incomparable Rush sound all the way through. As they say in \\"Far Cry,\\" \\"You can almost feel the current flowing. You can almost see the circuits blowing.\\"
B000GFLAI0|5.0|I wasn't so sure about this album before listening to it.  Reviewers had been comparing it to Time Out of Mind and Love & Theft.  I do like Time Out of Mind despite it lacking the warmth found on the other album Dylan made with producer Daniel Lanois, Oh Mercy (which is among my favorite Dylan albums).  Love & Theft was, however, an album that I really do not like.  The songs on that album lack cohesion and the production is somewhat muddled. <br /> <br />Although Modern Times does not differ a great deal from Love & Theft, the difference lies first and foremost in the more direct melodies and a crystal clear but yet warm production.  From my standpoint, it is as if Love & Theft were from the same recording sessions, simply the songs on it were B-sides with all the worthwhile material making it to Modern Times. <br /> <br />The highlight of this album is Workingman's Blues #2, with subtle passion and emotion throughout.  Other highlights include Spirit on the Water, Beyond the Horizon and When the Deals Goes Down.  The only track resembling being a filler is Someday Baby. <br /> <br />This album is in mine opinion close to being as good as Oh Mercy.  The mystic sound that makes Oh Mercy so special (recorded in New Orleans) is, however, lacking.  That layered sound is probably among Lanois major contribution but he is nowhere to be found on Modern Times.  Despite the production being crystal clear, the music is so delicately played that it doesn't hinder the album from having a warm feeling.  This is Dylan's best record since Oh Mercy and among his best in his career.  At 65, he still has some magic left in him. <br />
B0001L3LUE|5.0|This brilliant series of interviews with Robert McNamara should be required viewing for *anyone* before he or she is authorized to venture an opinion regarding what America should or should not do with its power. I do not begin my review because of any clear sense of the virtue or villainy of Bob McNamara's legacy as president of the Ford Motor Company, Secretary of Defense under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, and long-time president of the World Bank.<br /><br />Far from it, the spendidly drawn impression is how dangerously concentrated power becomes in the hands of fragile, myopic, regular men and women who in many--most?--cases want to do the right thing.<br /><br />McNamara's memory ranges from World War I to the extinction of River Blindness in Africa through the World Bank's efforts. For understandable reasons, the camera and the questions linger most on the Viet Nam era, for this is where McNamara took 'the world stage', as he puts it.<br /><br />Clearly enamored of John Kennedy, McNamara had a more complex relationship with Johnson, whom he admired but with whom he came to disagree in a process that led to McNamara's firing just shortly before Johnson made his epic decision not to run for reelection.<br /><br />As THE FOG OF WAR touches time and again upon the deliberations that framed the Bay of Pigs crisis and then the Southeast Asian war itself, one hears via the clarity of taped conversations how little we knew and, proverbially, how close we came to ultimate war.<br /><br />McNamara has passionate remarks to offer on the very timely matter of taking America's strength into battle when we have failed to convince our allies of that course.<br /><br />Kudos to McNamara for complicating his legacy even more by achieving astonshing things through some of the World Bank's better years.<br /><br />Required viewing.

B000OHZJ9Q|5.0|Porcupine tree is a band that is hard to categorize. They're music has evolved from far-flung spaced- out rave jams ( early 90's) all the way to their latest release ,which is more of a straight - on rock / prog attack. And an excellent one at that. On this album,the band explores the hollowing out of our youth by all the gadgets and electronic pacifiers at their disposal. This is a hard rocking album for P.T ( with notable exceptions on some tracks) and evokes a similar sound in places to Alice in Chains ( jar of flies) and Pink Floyd (dark side) but all buttoned up and expressed in only the way that Porcupine Tree can present it.  <br />The songs cascade, one from the other, in a meandering but structured sonic onslaught. Porcupine Tree's strength has always been in their layering of keybords and guitar, with subtle and somewhat dark lyrics. Fear Of A B.P. is no exception. This is music that needs to be explored as much as listened to. <br />After hearing this new release several times, I am convinced that it is destined to be a classic and, no doubt, a new pinnacle has been reached by P.T. <br />For anyone that is \\"on the fence \\" and unsure if they should purchase this, I would suggest doing so. The band deserves far more recognition than it has thus far recieved in the states.  <br />For new P.T. fans, it is an excellent introduction to the band and has a soundscape that is like nothing else out there. Enjoy... <br />
B00003CXD5|3.0|The Treasure of the Sierra Madre is a classic film starring one of the brightest stars of the era, Humphrey Bogart. Its themes are universal and timeless and the script features a line well known by the American culture. It follows three gold prospectors into the dirty desert where they mine tiny bits of gold. The threat of the elements, bandits, and each other slowly drive them apart and plant seeds of intense paranoia in their brains.<br /><br />It might seem pretty stereotypical to deem this movie a \\"man's film,\\" but really, that is what it is. The locations are far from beautiful, the actors are constantly unshaven and unclean, and the themes are about manhood. It isolates its audience, leaving women with little to relate to. I found it interesting in small sections but lacking as a whole.<br /><br />This DVD release features an entire disk filled with extra features including documentaries, trailers, and other goodies.<br /><br />I am sure that many people love this film and that it contains good acting, important themes, and great dialogue. However, my inability to relate to the events made it rather dull for me.

B000NVIXFK|5.0|Every Rush fan has their own conception of what the band's best work is. In almost every case, this is based on what time period that fan grew up in and discovered Rush. I, for example, find myself attached to the band's 80's material. Nevertheless, any true fan will find themselves enjoying Rush's material overall, from the 70s all the way to the present. And if you don't like a particular Rush album, just wait till the next one, as it is guaranteed to be different.<br /><br />Snakes and Arrows is no exception to this.<br /><br />For the most part, this album is the logical succession to the works released since 1993's Counterparts. What truly makes Snakes and Arrows stand out is the unique and refreshing use of acoustic instruments on almost every track. However, this is not \\"Folk Rush\\"! Nothing here, for instance, sounds like \\"Nobody's Hero.\\" Rather, the 6/12 string guitars, mandolin, mandola and bouzouki fill much of the space, and indeed, play much of the role that synthesizers once did. The musical coloring these instruments provide compensate for the lack of synths (although Geddy Lee does use a mellotron on this album - another new approach!). And production wise, the sound quality, mix and arrangements of these songs are perfect. The production is A+, and very reminiscent of Peter Collins (the best producer Rush ever worked with, in my humble opinion).<br /><br />Regarding individual performances, as always, each member shines: Neil Peart maintains his mantle of all-time percussion master, and his lyrics are very critical of the present state of the world. Geddy Lee's voice hasn't strained one bit with age, and, if anything, is becoming more and more accessible to those who are turned off by the \\"banshee wails\\" of his youth. His bass work, while prominent as always, takes on a deeper, fuller tone (though not muddy) and he seems to be giving the guitars more incentive to take the lead. Which leads me to the star of the album, Alex Lifeson. Not only does Alex branch out on new string instruments, but his lead work shows real maturity. His tone is excellent, and thank God he is no longer obsessed with whammy bar/vibrato overkill.<br /><br />Snakes and Arrows is ultimately just another Rush album that shows how \\"Canada's greatest export\\" still blows the competition way out of the water. This is not AOR Rush; repeated listenings are required to fully appreciate this effort, something I think many reviewers did not do prior to writing their review. All the instrumentals (three of them!) are great, and while \\"Far Cry,\\" the single, is superb, you'll also want to check out \\"The Way The Wind Blows,\\" \\"Bravest Face\\" and \\"We Hold On\\" for a good sampling of this album.<br /><br />On a final note to Rush fans: just buy it.does Alex branch out on new string instruments, but his lead work shows real maturity. His tone is excellent, and thank God he is no longer obsessed with whammy bar/vibrato overkill.  <br /> <br />Snakes and Arrows is ultimately just another Rush album that shows how \\"Canada's greatest export\\" still blows the competition way out of the water. This is not AOR Rush; repeated listenings are required to fully appreciate this effort, something I think many reviewers did not do prior to writing their review. All the instrumentals (three of them!) are great, and while \\"Far Cry,\\" the single, is superb, you'll also want to check out \\"The Way The Wind Blows,\\" \\"Bravest Face\\" and \\"We Hold On\\" for a good sampling of this album. <br /> <br />On a final note to Rush fans: just buy it.

B000O75F7C|4.0|Let the record show that I'm a hardcore PT fan. Do I have all the limited vinyl's? Yup. All the rare releases? Yes. And almost everything else they've released? You better believe it. PT is one of my favourite groups (and still one of the best kept secrets in music), so accusations of my review being `ungrounded', or my opinion being `too stuck up' isn't really fair. Ok, now for the review...<br /><br />Right off the bat, once I had learned that FoaPB was going to be overtly political, I was a bit taken aback. Both the video, artwork and website all depict images of 'corrupted' individuals who have been (somewhat) conditioned by the media, and have consequently become mindless and destructive individuals. My depiction may be harsh, but that's the air I feel it projects. I'm slightly disappointed that SW has made political commentary that has been made since the 70s by everyone and their grandma. Granted, works off of Signify and In Absentia had political content, but FoaPB seems... well, too clich&eacute;d. The \\"oh, let's run from the media\\" and \\"we're all doomed\\" ethos that's embedded in the lyrics of FoaPB has been made by so pop stars, celebs and whatnot, that it just seems silly in a PT context.<br /><br />A lot of people on the PT board keep mentioning that it's great to \\"finally\\" hear someone say something like this, but come on, this concept has been flogged to death, over and over. And the only difference I can spot - not counting the music, simply the lyrics - is that Lasse Hoile has done some (beautifully) disturbing artwork to reinforce the message. Fortunately, though, the vocals blend into the overall mix of the album, so listening to the lyrics will take several tries before you fully understanding their role in the music.<br /><br />Aside from my gripes with the political nature of the album, the music is spectacular as always. Aside from \\"My Ashes\\" sounding too much like a Blackfield song (SW has a very Aviv Geffen tone), and \\"Anesthetize\\" wandering off here and there [a few of the guitar riffs seemed uncertain, Lifeson's solo was decent (if you like hearing a tremolo exercise) and why, oh why, did RB include indie-rock xylophone runs?], the latter half of the album is truly lush and hypnotic.<br /><br />The one standout song, in my humble opinion, was \\"Way Out of Here,\\" which, is one of the few group-written songs. The energy it contains carries an emotive force that'll completely knock you down a few times, while you try and figure out what's coming. It's viscous and awe-inspiring, and it's unfair to simply say this song is disjointed, due to the emphasis on extended riffs.<br /><br />Sadly, in no way is FoaPB a new chapter in PT's catalogue. Rather it feels like the end of what both In Absentia and Deadwing began - heavy, guitar pieces driven (well, bass and percussion, too). At points it feels like a temper-tantrum, where SW gets out all of the heavy metal energy that's brewing inside him. And at others it's truly cinematic.<br /><br />If you can put aside lackluster political commentary, you'll enjoy what PT has to offer. While it may not be their best, I can't wait to see what doors they'll go through next. Recommended 4.5/5off here and there [a few of the guitar riffs seemed uncertain, Lifeson's solo was decent (if you like hearing a tremolo exercise) and why, oh why, did RB include indie-rock xylophone runs?], the latter half of the album is truly lush and hypnotic. <br /> <br />The one standout song, in my humble opinion, was \\"Way Out of Here,\\" which, is one of the few group-written songs. The energy it contains carries an emotive force that'll completely knock you down a few times, while you try and figure out what's coming. It's viscous and awe-inspiring, and it's unfair to simply say this song is disjointed, due to the emphasis on extended riffs. <br /> <br />Sadly, in no way is FoaPB a new chapter in PT's catalogue. Rather it feels like the end of what both In Absentia and Deadwing began - heavy, guitar pieces driven (well, bass and percussion, too). At points it feels like a temper-tantrum, where SW gets out all of the heavy metal energy that's brewing inside him. And at others it's truly cinematic.  <br /> <br />If you can put aside lackluster political commentary, you'll enjoy what PT has to offer. While it may not be their best, I can't wait to see what doors they'll go through next. Recommended 4.5/5
B000O75F7C|3.0|I am not a lifelong Porcupine Tree expert like many of the reviewers here. I'm a late entrant to this game, and recently became a big fan of In Absentia and Deadwing (while dabbling in their earlier works too). It's true that this new album further explores the musical frontiers first envisioned on those albums, though these explorations don't always lead to great musical discoveries. This album is a good progression of the Porcupine Tree game plan, but much of the instrumental crunch and personal passion of the last two albums seems to be falling to professional competence and lyrical crankiness. The prime example is the album's centerpiece, the 17-minute \\"Anesthetize\\" which is not the slow-burn epic that it tries to be, instead descending into longwinded instrumental noodling and amateurish lyrics like \\"What's the point? What can money buy?\\" In fact, the lyrics throughout this album take on the aspects of some strange midlife crisis, with Wilson becoming obsessed with predictable platitudes about unhappy childhoods and media saturation. Good concepts to be sure, but they've been done much better elsewhere.<br /><br />Furthermore, Wilson has never had a very strong singing voice though he has traditionally been able to make a vocal impact with the band's strong instrumental skills as a backdrop. However, here that just doesn't work, as Wilson's songwriting seems to be divorcing itself from his vocal range. Fortunately, this album is saved by a few generally strong songs - particularly \\"Way Out of Here\\" which is the album's only track that integrates different musical styles (from new-age balladry to technical metal) as seamlessly as in the band's previous works, while the insistent opener \\"Fear of a Blank Planet\\" and the sinister closer \\"Sleep Together\\" are excellent reinforcements of Porcupine Tree's historical strengths. Unfortunately, overall this album leaves an impression of a passionate band, and their brilliant leader, settling into complacency and bitterness. In one song, Wilson sings \\"I never wanna be old,\\" but this album may indicate his inability to resist the inevitable. [~doomsdayer520~]ness. In one song, Wilson sings \\"I never wanna be old,\\" but this album may indicate his inability to resist the inevitable. [~doomsdayer520~]

B000NVIXFK|1.0|Snakes and Arrows . . . a much anticipated CD from my favorite group Rush.  I admit, I took the buildup hype hook line and sinker.  The youthful presence of  Nick \\"Foo Fighters\\" Raskulinecz was certainly going to energize these 3 great musicians to new heights . . . a proverbial kick in the pants to propel them forward after the production failure that was their previous effort- Vapor Trails.  <br /> <br />I was wrong.  Snakes and Arrow is an overwrought (for Rush), shoe horned, lyrically inane production that provides no memorable material of any kind from Rush.  <br /> <br />The opening song Far Cry is a semi catchy little piece that desperately screams for a ripping Alex Lifeson guitar solo at its midpoint, but alas the listener only gets another Alex LIfeson guitar lesson in atmospheric layering.  Still though, not a bad start.  <br /> <br />Then comes the next 4 monoliths (aka SwordAngelBowlDrift) of plodding, frankly boring songs had this long time Rush fan pining for the days when a Rush \\"side A\\" was a veritable treasure trove of hard/prog rock musicianship and execution.  Workin Them Angels is the most memorable tune of the this fourplex and that's not saying much.   <br /> <br />The rest of the non instrumental songs are just plain forgettable.  Which brings me to the instrumentals. <br /> <br />The best one by far is the Main Monkey Business, which is a small bite of Fillet Mignon in the boot leather tough piece of cube steak that is Snakes and Arrows.  <br /> <br />Production wise Snakes and Arrows is light years better than Vapor Trails.   <br /> <br />Lee, Lifeson and Peart certainly offer brief forays into some interesting musicianship on Snakes and Arrows, but by and large it's a been there done that expedition.  Snakes and Arrows tries to hard to be \\"progressively rootsy\\" and in turn that produces soul less, numbing music.  <br /> <br />Neil Peart used to be able to wrap symbolism and social comment into a rich storyline that would keep Rush geeks talking and exploring the content for days.  Now, Peart just takes out the hammer and tells the listener throughout Snakes and Arrows that world is bad place full of bad people who live behind iron gates and you best just run home and hide.  Lyrically Snakes and Arrows may go down as Peart's most inane, vapid and grooveless efforts ever with Rush.  In parts of Snakes and Arrows Lee's vocals almost have a \\"are you kiddin me with this stuff\\" subliminal undertone to them. <br /> <br />Maybe next time Rush and Nick R.  <br /> <br /> <br />

0143036742|5.0|Rumours have it that Marina Lewycka's first novel was initially placed under \\"agriculture\\" on the book shelves. Ukrainian tractors don't sound like a good topic for a highly enjoyable reading experience. Yet it is! While a history of tractors features in the narrative as a sub-stream, the story really is about family - history and complex relationships across generations and cultures.  All those elements are packaged in a vivid, yet easy-going language, filled with humour and gentle satire.<br /><br />The story is set in the Ukrainian immigrant community in England and centres around Nicolai, a 84 year old widower who has set his eyes on a thirty-something, full-bosomed blonde Valentina, a would-like-to-be immigrant. His intention to marry her gets his two daughters onto the scene, anxious to stop such a mismatch. Despite their intense efforts and intrigues, however, their attempt to obstruct doesn't succeed.  \\"She exploded into our lives like a fluffy pink grenade...\\" Written from the perspective of Nadia, the younger of the two daughters, and through her discussions with \\"Big Sis\\" Vera, the reader follows the upheavals that this new reality in their fathers' life creates. Suspicions are rife that Valentina has plans beyond looking after a new husband and that Nicolai is being exploited in more ways than one. The sisters themselves carry baggage from the past that they need to put aside or resolve in order to show a united front to their father's situation.  In the process, events from the family history come to light that explain to some degree their different approaches to the problem at hand and different relationship each has had with their father and their late mother.<br /><br />At one level Lewycka's novel is just a fun read, a family saga that shines with lively dialogue and witty comments on the reality of the lives of the central characters.  At another level, she seamlessly integrates her reflections on aging and the needs and vulnerabilities of seniors and the challenges these present for the next generation to handle.  Finally, through flashbacks into Nikolai's life, the author provides the reader with insights into the family's background that makes the characters into who they have become. Nicolai and Valentina in particular come to live in the story and one can find parallels to people we all know.  All the parts are expertly joined so that these elements don't feel like overwhelming the primary storyline. A highly recommended book. [Friederike Knabe]eniors and the challenges these present for the next generation to handle.  Finally, through flashbacks into Nikolai's life, the author provides the reader with insights into the family's background that makes the characters into who they have become. Nicolai and Valentina in particular come to live in the story and one can find parallels to people we all know.  All the parts are expertly joined so that these elements don't feel like overwhelming the primary storyline. A highly recommended book. [Friederike Knabe]
B00005JPAO|3.0|\\"The Queen\\" is only a portait of Queen Elizabeth.  That was established early on in the first scene when she is posing for the portait painter.  With that, we are warned that what follows is not going to be \\"truth\\" in as much as a biography or documentary.  It is the film's \\"impression\\" of the queen at a time when the monarchy was forced to accept the tragic events of Diana's death and to join with the rest of its subjects in grief.  Therefore, the portrait reminds us that the focus is squarely upon the Queen herself and no one else.  In spite of all the biographies about the British royal family, not one of them can be considered to have an authoritative perspective.  The Royal Family have endeavored for centuries not to allow daylight in upon the magic of monarchy.  They know that to do so would invite a host of trouble.  Such daylight upon magic would bring them all to Hector's and Hilda's, as Prince Philip stated in the fim.  It's a delicate balance that they must preserve.  So, what we get from this film is, as usual, merely an impression but certainly not the truth.  The stag motif, however, helps us to understand the message that lies beneath. <br /> <br />The stag is indeed an interesting additive, and it is the most intriging figure in the film.  Many viewers have interpreted the stag as a representation of Diana.  I can certainly understand the reasoning behind that interpretation.  However, let's go a little further into the stag motif.  If you miss the motif, you miss the connection.  I will say right now that the stag is not in fact Diana, but the Queen herself.  Why?  Let's review the number of times that verbal references to \\"stag\\" are made and that crucial time when the stag appears. <br /> <br />When the Queen walks down a long corridor at Balmoral to take a call from the Prime Minister, notice the stag heads mounted on the walls along that corridor.  The stag is therefore connected with \\"monarchy\\" or imperialism. <br /> <br />Just before the stag appears in the river scene, the Queen is sitting down.  She has had a car accident because she was driving too fast along a rocky road and is now stranded in the river.  She begins to cry.  Then she turns and sees the stag.  The Queen is an active deer stalker, and that is what has kept her in such good physical shape to this day.  She identifies with deer.  And in the scene when the stag appears, he seems to identify with her.  Both the Queen and stag establish eye contact with each other, hence the camera closeup on the stag as he gazes at her and she at him.  She calls him \\"a beauty,\\" because to her he is something ethereal, magical, and \\"otherworldly\\" just as monarchy is to the public.  The stag is a sacrificial figure in this scene, although the Queen does not quite see him as sacrifical at that point.  To her, he is \\"a beauty\\" only.  She will later learn what he represents to her. <br /> <br />After the princes hear of the news of their mother's death, Prince Philip encourages them to take out their anger on a stag that has been known to appear on the 40,000-acre property of Balmoral.  To Philip the stag is nothing more than a deer.  He never quite gets the significance of the stag's meaning.  When Philip tries to get the boys out in the fresh air for deer stalking, the stag managed to elude them.  The stag has wandered off to neighboring property.  He has left the Balmoral estate. <br /> <br />Later in the film, Prince Philip tells the Queen that the stag has been shot on neighboring property by a banker who had come out for a day's shooting. <br /> <br />The Queen drives over to the neighboring property to see the stag in the cleaning room.  There he hangs by his hind legs.  He has been decapitated, and that's an important point.  The caretaker tells the Queen that the stag is a 14-pointer, an \\"imperial.\\"  It is there in that room that the Queen releases her emotions.  She hopes that \\"he did not suffer much\\" when the shooting party had to follow him for milesbefore finishing him off.  She begins to identify with the stag even more in this scene.  She understands that the stag has been sacrificed.  I think she now begins to see herself as a sacrifical object.  As she examines the stag's head on the table in the cleaning room, she touches the point on the stag's cheek where he has been wounded.  She identifies with the stag even more at this point.  She looks at the head, no doubt remembering all the beheaded kings and queens in the historical past, and she probably recalls how important it is to connect with her people at a time when she is so reluctant to do so.  The \\"stag,\\" as the Queen, is going to be brought down, but for a purpose.  And she learned that she had to modernize, to reinvent the monarchy in order to reconnect with her people with whom she had been so out of touch. <br /> <br />The Queen feels a connection with this stag, precisely at a time when she herself is being \\"hunted and brought down\\" by a citizenry who demands her presence in London for Diana's funeral.  She is finally brought to her knees when she is forced to deliver an address to the nation about Diana.  But she is not accustomed to demands.  She is as vulnerable as the stag.  She vainly tries to remain elusive at Balmoral but to no avail. <br /> <br />Like the stag and like Diana, the Queen is also a hunted figure by her subjects.   <br /> <br />Thanks to all who read this, and I hope you reply to my review with thoughts of your own. <br /> <br />
B00005JPPI|2.0|I was trying to answer a question about what movies I'd seen recently.  When I said I'd seen \\"Fracture,\\" my mind went blank; and I couldn't remember who was in it or what it was about.  I decided that if I reviewed it, maybe it'd come back to me.  The title and the film seem disconnected to me.  I'm sure there was a connection between the word \\"Fracture\\" and the picture, but it sounds like something Hitchcock would have directed.  Now \\"Shot in the Head\\" might have brought back what Ted Crawford does to his wife Jennifer.<br /><br />Director Gregory Hoblit made a name for himself as the Executive Producer of the TV series \\"NYPD Blue.\\"  He directs this stylish thriller that has the suspense of a chess match, brainy but not that interesting to watch.<br /><br />Anthony Hopkin will probably always be identified with his amazing Oscar-winning performance from \\"Silence of the Lambs.\\"  So many of his characters seem like variations on that spooky character.  Ryan Gosling was a great rebel romantic in \\"The Notebook\\" and received an Oscar nomination for \\"Half Nelson\\" last year, which I know at least 24 people have seen.  As DA Willy Beachum, he's too flawed to be entirely likeable, but one does admire the character's perseverance.  Embeth Davidtz plays Crawford's wife Jennifer in a brief appearance.  Her role in the small film \\"Junebug\\" was filled with energy.  Her face is one that leaves you trying to recall where you'd seen it.  While I couldn't come up with \\"Bridget Jones Diary\\" or \\"Schindler's List\\" anymore than I could recall the movie \\"Fracture\\" when asked, she does a nice job as the wife of the wealthy but cold Ted Crawford.  One really can't blame her for seeking out police negotiator Rob Nunnally played by Billy Burke, who I did recognize from one of my favorite episodes of TV's \\"Monk.\\"  Burke does a good job of playing the distraught lover, although one wonders how one used to being in the middle of crisis events suddenly loses it on the courtroom steps.  David Strathairn turns in another amazingly tightly controlled performance that is well suited to this film, brainy but boring, or \\"Good Night & Good Luck.\\"<br /><br />My favorite part of the film was Rosamund Pike as high-powered lawyer Nikki Gardener.  Hoblit takes us to the Gardner family's home for Thanksgiving, which introduces us to her father, a judge, but also allows Pike to show numerous levels between the professional and the personal family life.  Her face is familiar from double-o-seven's \\"Die Another Day,\\" \\"Pride & the Prejudice\\" and \\"The Libertine.\\"  [I think was one of the 24 people who actually watched \\"The Libertine\\" all the way to the end!]<br /><br />\\"Fracture\\" really fractured for me at the end.  Without giving any spoiler, it seemed that someone as bright as Ted Crawford would surely be able to have contemplated the lame-brained technicality with which Beachum wraps up the plot & assures us that good guys win.
